It will be a tax policy that will put incentive and productivity back into the Australian economy. This budget introduces three new taxes that affect business. Labor has a policy for a tax cut—to the superannuation contributions tax. We will reduce the rate from 15 per cent to 13 per cent. We want retirement savings to work for the retirement years—not be eaten up by taxes, fees and charges. And I give the House this guarantee: we do not support the Treasurer's policy of `work till you drop'. Labor will always protect the age pension and the superannuation system.

For families, the government has produced a policy for the next election, but not a plan for Australia's future. The new lump sum payment is compensating families for bad government policy—its inability to overcome the family debt crisis. More than 600,000 Australian families have family benefit debts averaging $900. They are unlikely to ever see the lump sum payment—it will be eaten up by their existing debt. The government is spending money without necessarily solving problems. In this regard, it needs to take a lesson from families themselves.

Raising a child is not a temporary job. It takes long-term commitment, planning and care. And that is the way governments should approach family policy: don't patch it up for today; get it right for the future. That is what a Labor government will do. Families need more assistance and we will provide it in a more effective way:
resolving the family debt crisis;
providing greater incentive for families in the interaction between the tax and social security systems;

and paying the assistance when the families need it most—not at the end of the year, but fortnightly as the bills come in and as the children need new clothes, shoes and school books. Let us pay it when the families need the support.

Tonight I have outlined the way in which Labor will answer the cries for help I have been hearing across Australia; cries for social investment and opportunity—health, education and community services. Those cries are growing louder every day and this budget will not silence them. It is not a budget of opportunity. It is a statement of opportunism.

talk.start.para: —I warn the member for Paterson!
—The government has had eight years to address these problems and its only response is an election spending spree. It has run out of ideas and it has run out of puff.

speech.para: I am sensing that the people want to move past this Prime Minister. They are not really interested in his one obsession: his place in the Guinness Book of Records. The Australian people want to get on with the future—not the past, the future.
The Australian people cannot afford to wait another three years:
to restore bulk-billing and save Medicare;
to establish a dental program and vaccinate our children;
to make education more affordable and tackle youth unemployment.

As a parliament, we have a heavy responsibility. We cannot afford to wait another three years to answer the cries for help. Australia needs a new government—a government that solves problems and believes in opportunity for all; a government that delivers better services, fully paid for; a government that uses our prosperity for a good social purpose and a sound social purpose for the future; and a government that governs for the people, not the powerful.

That is my goal: to give this country a government every bit as big and warm hearted as the Australian people themselves; a government as big and generous as the country we love. That is what I want to achieve through an Australian Labor government.
Debate (on motion by Mr Abbott) adjourned.

talk.start.para: to move:

interjection.para: (1) recognises the invaluable contribution that carers make to our community;

(2) acknowledges that carers need and deserve practical support from the community to meet the significant challenges that they face on a daily basis, whether those challenges be financial, emotional or physical;

(3) realises that it is not always desirable, possible or practical for carers and the people they care for to live in the same house and therefore they should be entitled to choose the living arrangements that best suit their individual circumstances;
(4) praises the Howard Government for providing carers and the people they care for with a choice as to the living arrangements that best suit their circumstances as part of the 2004 Budget;

(5) commends the Howard Government for providing carers receiving the Carers Payment with a one-off payment of $1000 and $600 for Carer Allowance recipients for each eligible care receiver they provide care for as part of the 2004 Budget in recognition of their contribution to the community;

(6) supports the Howard Government's provision of an in-home respite service of up to 5 hours per school week for young carers at risk of leaving secondary school or equivalent vocational education as part of the 2004 Budget;

(7) commends the Howard Government for providing young at-risk carers one fortnight of respite care each year to undertake activities such as study for exams, training or recreation as part of the 2004 Budget;

(8) strongly supports the Howard Government for guaranteeing, when matched by States and Territories, up to four weeks a year respite for parents over 70 years of age who are caring for a son or daughter with a disability and, for parents aged 65 to 69 years of age who need to spend time in hospital, two weeks respite as part of the 2004 Budget, and calls on the States and Territories to demonstrate their support for carers by matching this commitment; and

(9) commends the Howard Government for initiating a strategy to work with the States and Territories and the carer and disability sectors to develop options to help ageing carers plan for the future when they can no longer provide care for their disabled children. (Notice given 13 May 2004.)

business.start.para: The DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Causley) took the chair at 9.40 a.m.

talk.start.para: —Steve and Lillian Schembri, who reside in my electorate, were born, grew up and were educated in Australia. They were compelled to leave the country with their parents at the age of 18. Mr and Mrs Schembri were both forced to renounce Australian citizenship at the age of 18 in order to retain Maltese citizenship after they moved to Malta with their parents. This was a requirement of Maltese law at the time. This law was changed in 2000. They have maintained close and enduring ties with Australia through their numerous relatives in this country. They see their future and the future of their children in Australia, yet the government denies them the ability to reacquire Australian citizenship because they are over the age of 25.

speech.para: Several of Mr Schembri's relatives, all citizens of Australia, are known to me and my staff through their involvement in community activities and service. Mr Schembri is a qualified solid plasterer and has been offered employment in Australia. His trade qualification is relatively rare and highly desirable in this country. Maltese law, prior to 2000, required young people of Maltese descent to renounce their Australian citizenship between their 18th and 19th birthdays in order to retain their Maltese citizenship. Those failing to do so became ineligible for free tertiary education in Malta and were unable to hold certain jobs, access social security benefits or purchase property without approval.

While the Australian government says it is unable to provide a proper estimate of numbers, it is understood that there are, at most, a couple of thousand Maltese Australians who have renounced their Australian citizenship because of this provision. It is highly unlikely that every single eligible person will apply in this regard. Minister Hardgrave has indicated that the Maltese community has raised the issue with him and that it is under consideration. I consider the minister's position to be a cop-out, given the history and given the unfair application to Maltese Australians. It is not immediately clear why this needs to be in line with age requirements on citizenship by descent, other than from a sense of bureaucratic tidiness. Meanwhile, many people are suffering needlessly from this law, and Australia has very little to gain and much to lose by denying many former Australians the chance to contribute meaningfully to the Australian community.

In my electorate there are many Maltese Australians and many who suffer from this inequitable situation. I think it is about time that we changed the law, given the discriminatory nature of its application. Labor is looking to consider this matter and to change the law in order to ensure that people such as Steve and Lillian Schembri will be able to become full Australian citizens, as they were prior to going to Malta, where they were forced to renounce their Australian citizenship. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I feel very moved at this time to talk about the neglect of roads and branch lines in country New South Wales, especially in my electorate of Parkes. This is at a time when thankfully the coalition, and John Anderson in particular, has announced the extension of the Roads to Recovery program, with another $1.2 billion over four years. The 14 local governments in the Parkes area have fallen over with relief that the Commonwealth is doing that. On top of that, a further $1 billion for country roads was announced in the budget. It is to be announced soon how that money will be disbursed. But we also have well over $3 billion in the budget towards road and rail infrastructure. This is very necessary. The neglect of country roads and rail in my electorate is very damaging.

speech.para: The West Wyalong to Burcher line is being closed. We have more trucks on the roads and less maintenance being given to them. I felt so strongly about it that I recently mailed out a request for people to send in a response about what they felt about branch line closures and maintenance around my electorate. We have over 2,000 responses by people who did not just have to put a cross in a box and send it back; they had to put their own stamp on it and mail it. That is an enormous response from an electorate when we consider that most of those people live in towns. I hope that, on behalf of my constituents, Andrew Stoner, the leader of The Nationals in New South Wales, will present their responses to the state government—to Mr Costa and to the minister for roads. There will be road closures in my electorate if the state government continues to ignore the result of failing to repair country branch lines.

Thankfully, the ARTC is taking over and getting $540 million to spend on the main lines in New South Wales in a month's time—that is, before the end of this financial year—but it is still up to the state government to pay the cost of maintaining those branch lines, which they are not doing. Obviously, they are considering closing a number of them. It is vital that Carl Scully and Mr Costa think deeply before they do any more closures and stop spending money and that they back up what the Commonwealth is trying to do for transport and communications in the electorate of Parkes.

talk.start.para: —This week's budget has done little to advance the core concept of social sustainability: social systems such as health and education and the wellbeing of our community. When we take a look at our social systems we find a health system in excruciating pain and an education system starved of funding. The Howard government knows that Medicare needs fixing but it insists on bandaid solutions and cover-ups. The government had a perfect opportunity with this budget to inject much-needed funding into the health system, but fixing Medicare is not in the Treasurer's leadership campaign strategy; he obviously bought that through an `Acme' kit. If we turn to education we find a similar story: the very crucibles of advancement being starved of funding.

speech.para: In Bass I have urged the government to support some simple environmental initiatives but so far there is no support there either. I refer to initiatives such as the extension of the wood heater program to combat the declining air quality, the need to develop the sewerage capacities of Launceston due to the current inadequacies of the Tea Tree Bend plant, and strategic planning for coastal town developments for towns such as Bridport.

I recently wrote to the environment minister seeking support to examine the environmental and social impacts of increasing water flow through the Cataract Gorge in Launceston to address the health of the South Esk River. I am still hopeful that the minister will respond to this initiative and to the other measures that will restore the quality of the Esk River. A clear picture is emerging: the government is not sponsoring social sustainability, it does not protect the vulnerable and it does not even support equity in health and equity in education.

This budget is an election platform, not a foundation for social sustainability. The Costello push for leadership has begun by delivering tax cuts and family benefits for a very lucky few. This budget fails to deliver tax relief or assistance for three out of five Australian families, including thousands of Tasmanians. In Bass only 7.7 per cent of income earners receive in excess of $1,000 a week. As we see, there will be a tax cut for only some families. And what the Treasurer did not announce on Tuesday night was that the $600 payment to FTB recipients would be first used to offset any outstanding debts—and we know that they average $900.

I also want to use this opportunity to explain how angry and disgusted I am that this government failed to fund the pneumococcal vaccine. In Tasmania in 2002, 61 people contracted pneumococcal meningitis and 11 died; in 2003, 86 people contracted the disease. That is a high proportion in relation to the number of people who contracted the disease and the number of fatalities in the rest of Australia. I call on this government to finally do something and fund that important, independently recommended vaccine.

In the forthcoming election the people of Bass will have a very clear point of differentiation: a Latham Labor government—with its key platform of equity, fairness and opportunity for all—or more of the same Liberal arrogance. We have an option: opportunity for all or opportunity for the few.

subdebateinfo.title: Parramatta Electorate: Ermington-Rydalmere Betty Cuthbert Festival

talk.start.para: —The Melbourne Olympics saw a shy, but incredibly endearing, young Australian come splashing onto the world stage. She stunned the world at the age of 18 by winning three gold medals in athletics. From that moment, Betty Cuthbert became Australia's golden girl. After injury forced her withdrawal from the Tokyo Games, she then came back with an extraordinary victory in the 400 metres in Rome, thus becoming, with four gold medals, the most successful Australian athlete in Olympic history. You may not be aware that Betty comes from Ermington in the heart of my electorate of Parramatta, where she and her twin sister and their family grew up. The family still has a nursery in Ermington. She is our most celebrated citizen, and the main street of Ermington is called Betty Cuthbert Avenue.

speech.para: There is another extraordinary group of people in Ermington and they are gathered around the Burnside Family Learning Centre. They are a group of families, particularly mothers, who are concerned for the future of their kids; they want the best for them. They came and saw me and said, `What can we do to improve the opportunities for our kids?' There were about 20 mothers and we talked and met together quite a few times. Out of those meetings came this idea of a festival that would celebrate the best in Ermington. We would pick the young kids in Ermington who had most excelled in sport, academia and elsewhere, and bring them together. We would invite all of the other people—the churches, the community organisations, the Police Citizens Youth Club et cetera—and we would have a day celebrating the achievements of Ermington. So, with a bit of trepidation, I rang Betty Cuthbert in Perth, where she now lives in the Margaret River area, and said, `Would you be the patron of this festival and come back to Ermington and open it for us?'

I was delighted and we were all very excited when she agreed. I just want to acknowledge the organisers of the Ermington-Rydalmere Betty Cuthbert Festival, which takes place this Saturday. It will be opened by Betty Cuthbert. The organisers include: Steve Hantos; Reverend Trevor Lunney; Michelle Lenard; Gayle Lazonby, who was a driving force with the Burnside Family Learning Centre; Tamayne Dickens; Les Farquhar; Darren Mooney; Michael Maughan; Val Style; Adrian Hallet; Brenda Adams, who has done a huge amount of the voluntary work; Amanda Daly; Fari Salimi; John Burne; Anne Hurst; Lynn Byrne; Kel Durney; Tanya Gadiel; Tara George; Maria Nuchanatanon; Trudy Paterson; Reg Style; Phil Green; and my own staff members, Peter Kaye-Smith and Allan Croft. This Saturday is a moment we have been looking forward to. We have raised lots of money. We have arranged jumping castles, live entertainment and fairy floss—the whole thing. But, primarily, I want to acknowledge the extraordinary inspiration which Betty Cuthbert has given to this nation over the course of her life and also the great will and community spirit of the people of Ermington.

talk.start.para: —I was asked by the student association from the Bunbury TAFE to present a petition, which I will do at the end of my address, opposing the abolition of the Educational Textbook Subsidy Scheme. They travelled for over two hours from Bunbury to my electorate to ask me to present this petition to the House. They did not give it to their own MP, the member for Forrest, because they were not confident that he was actually interested in making submissions on their behalf. Apparently, he did not even give them the courtesy of a response to their correspondence. I was very happy indeed to agree to their request but extremely unhappy that the petition needed to be made at all. The students hope that in presenting this petition during the May sittings they might be successful and prevail upon the government to maintain the scheme, which allows students an eight per cent discount on the cost of eligible textbooks. Of course, this week's budget has dashed those hopes and condemns these students and others like them to further unreasonable hardship.

speech.para: The Educational Textbook Subsidy Scheme was introduced initially, as we know, to offset the impact of the GST. As we also know, the GST is still with us, and growing. The Educational Textbook Subsidy Scheme should still be with us as well. The failure to extend the scheme indefinitely highlights the government's bad faith on this issue—and, as an aside, I trust that the Democrats have learnt their lesson. This petition argues that the abolition of the subsidy is, in effect, an extra tax of some $40 or more per year on some of the most disadvantaged members of our society. That figure is borne out by a survey undertaken by the vice-chancellors called Paying their way: a survey of Australian undergraduate university student finances, 2000. It confirms that the average annual expenditure by students on textbooks—and this would apply to TAFE as well—was around $368, with the average for full-time students being $396. These are 2000 figures and, even with those now out-of-date figures, the removal of the eight per cent subsidy will mean an immediate annual increase of around $32.

That might not seem like a lot of money to some of us, but having to find that additional money means that students have to make a choice between working, attending classes or even eating. A March article in the University of Canberra's journal Monitor reported that the Salvation Army were overrun with students at the start of the academic year seeking money to help them pay their fees. A spokesperson for the Salvation Army said:

quote.para: They [the students] were worried if they paid their fees, they wouldn't be able to eat. It was a choice of eat or do the course.

speech.para: That is what this government is imposing on the students of Australia. Although a lot of people find it mildly amusing that the Treasurer is urging young people to produce a baby for the country, he is making it impossible for that baby to be educated. He has given big tax cuts to the wealthy in this community while leaning hard on the next generation—our students—who are having to make a choice between eating and studying. It is not a choice that anyone in this society should be required to make. I hereby table the petition.
The honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House, the planned abolition of the Educational Textbook Subsidy Scheme (ETSS) by the Federal Government on the 1st July 2004.
The abolition of the 8% Subsidy will cause considerable financial hardship for many students and their families.

With the cost of full years textbooks in the Tertiary and Post Secondary education sectors frequently being over $500, the abolition of this subsidy is in effect an extra tax of $40 or more per annum on some of the most disadvantaged members of society.
It will also affect the many millions of Australian parents buying textbooks for school aged children It is a tax on education and knowledge.
It is certainly a disincentive to study at a time when fees for training and education are constantly climbing.
Your petitioners therefore ask the House to stop the abolition of the Educational Textbook Subsidy Scheme (ETSS).
from 1,039 citizens.

talker.name: Slipper, Peter, MP
Mr SLIPPER
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance and Administration

talk.start.para: —There is nothing like a tragedy to draw a community together. On the Sunshine Coast in December a 13-year-old boy, Daniel Morcombe, was abducted from a bus stop. As a community, the Sunshine Coast has been drawn very close together as a result of this particular tragedy. The police have been doing a wonderful job, endeavouring to find information about Daniel's whereabouts. The whole community has come together to support his family and the other students at Siena Catholic College, which he attended. I have been incredibly moved by the stoic fortitude of Daniel's parents and the way in which they have carried themselves during this very difficult time. Posters have been put up around the community. A television campaign has been mounted. Printers like Mike Brooks of LEP Colour Printers have produced posters at no charge, and other printers have also supported the cause. Red ribbons are being worn throughout the Sunshine Coast to indicate support for the campaign to find Daniel Morcombe and to indicate support for Daniel's siblings and his parents. Australian Story highlighted the tragedy which has befallen the Morcombe family and the Sunshine Coast more generally.

speech.para: The fact that a child can disappear from a public place must strike fear in the hearts of all parents, regardless of where they live. Australia claims to be a civilised society—and I suppose compared with certain other parts of the world we have a lot to be proud of—but I have to say that, as an elected representative in the national parliament, I am very disturbed to find that in 2003 a child was able to be abducted and disappear without trace—and, despite the best efforts of his family, the police and the entire community, no trace has as yet been found of him.

I say to the Morcombe family that my best wishes and prayers are with them at this time. This has been an entirely bipartisan issue in our community. There was a rodeo held recently, and the mayor rode a bull and unfortunately was tossed and had his back broken. I wish Joe Natoli, Mayor of Maroochy Shire, a good recovery. Daniel's disappearance is a tragedy. I hope that we are able to find out what has happened to Daniel Morcombe. It would be wonderful if he could be found alive and well.

talk.start.para: (Hon. I.R. Causley)—Order! In accordance with standing order 275A the time for members' statements has concluded.

debate.para: Debate resumed from 1 April, on motion by Mr Abbott:

motion.para: That the House take note of the paper.

debate.para: upon which Mr Snowdon moved by way of amendment:
That the following words be added at the end of the motion:
“and the Prime Minister's and Leader of the Opposition's speeches of 30 March 2004 to the Prime Minister's motion relating to ADF personnel in or around Iraq”

talk.start.para: —We live in a time when journalists will use us to say things to support or discredit our leaders and, when they do not quite get the answer they want, twist our words ever so slightly to imply what they want. This debate on Iraq has been dubious from the beginning. I was never in favour of sending troops there, for exactly the reasons that are coming out now. We do not know for how long they will be committed if it is left to the Americans. We are, after all, part of an invading force that has removed a country's leader and is now putting in place a government that by its very nature of appointment is supposed to be a puppet of the USA. This is not a recipe for success in the Middle East. The Iraqi affair has really had nothing to do with terrorism. The weapons of mass destruction are not there—and no-one really knows whether they ever were—and the world is being deflected from putting its energies into stopping terrorism.

speech.para: Australians should not be a part of the Iraq conflict. They should never have gone. This was a political war, one the Bush family wanted to have to make up for not finishing the first Gulf War. But Australia has very professional and successful troops. They have shown that they can keep out of trouble and still do a good job under very difficult conditions and leaders. Australians have always been well respected and able to carry out military and peacekeeping duties in an unequalled fashion. I am very proud of our troops, but they cannot be used as pawns in a political war.

Mark Latham is right in wanting to withdraw the troops from Iraq before next Christmas. I think they should come home as soon as possible. They do have other duties that they could and should have been doing closer to home. But that is not to say that our troops will never be used to assist countries that require help with peacekeeping. We have a number of small forces in our region at present, doing a fantastic job. I visited some of them myself recently in East Timor; I have the greatest admiration for the work they do in sometimes very basic situations.

As far as Iraq is concerned, there needs to be a lot more development work done there. It has been stripped of its economy and its ability to act independently. There will be a role for some time to come in helping to put this country back together. But any assistance should be through the United Nations on a much more practical basis—not a political one. When the UN can again take up its role as mediator and peacekeeper, it is likely to ask all the countries under its umbrella to help sort this mess out, and that I am sure would include Australia. Labor believes that Australia has a moral obligation to deliver the strongest level of economic and humanitarian aid to Iraq possible, given our involvement in the original invasion and the most recent World Bank-UN needs assessment, which indicates a large shortfall in the aid funding for the Iraqi people.

Mark Latham rightly pointed out that the troops currently in place in Iraq should come home. I believe that too. The picture is tainted over there. When there is a situation where peacekeeping is required and the invading forces have gone home, then there will be an opportunity to reassess any UN resolutions that could request assistance from us and other peacekeeping forces around the world. That is a choice for the new government. If a new, Labor government believes that we should concentrate our efforts closer to home and on Australian soil then I believe that is the direction that should be taken. It should be a measured and practical response, not a political one to use as a tool at election time.

By the way, what is the point of having intelligence briefings that are deficient in vital information? And isn't it interesting that the Prime Minister seems to know word for word what those briefings apparently contained? Not only that, but isn't it conceivable that some of those briefings might actually contain the truth that the Prime Minister does not want to hear? We live in peculiar times when these secret briefings are spread over the front pages of morning newspapers. Now we have this added dilemma of the abuse of Iraqi prisoners. This is not helping anyone's cause in trying to take the moral high ground in this debate.

These prisoners may have been fighting against coalition forces but one man's terrorist is another man's freedom fighter. Only the courts should judge whether they are guilty of some crime. They should be treated as human beings. That is part of the Geneva Convention. It is a question of ensuring that abuses of human rights are not condoned. The Western nations have responsibility in ensuring that justice is done and is seen to be done, without treating prisoners like animals.
If one reads resolution 58/187 of the United Nations General Assembly, dated March 2004 and entitled Protection of human rights and fundamental freedoms while countering terrorism, it reaffirms:

quote.para: ... the fundamental importance, including in the response to terrorism and the fear of terrorism, of respecting all human rights and fundamental freedoms and the rule of law.

speech.para: This resolution reaffirms the basic tenets of the stance of the United Nations in the light of current events. The United Nations must be allowed to set the international rights of the world. There is no good to come of denying responsibility, either. If we are in coalition, we are in coalition. It is the whole which has the responsibility. No-one should pass the buck. We ought to have known what was going on and we ought to be able to speak up if it is inappropriate. As our shadow spokesman for foreign affairs, Kevin Rudd, said at a doorstop recently:

quote.para: Unfortunately John Howard needs to read the III Geneva Convention and work out that it is a Howard Government legal obligation to provide for the proper treatment of Iraqi POWs...why do we have these things called the III Geneva Convention and the IV Geneva Convention? They were agreed in 1949 because the international community looked at the horror of World War II and decided there had to be a better way to govern the treatment of POWs and civilians in times of war. Australia signed that in 1949 and under the Menzies Government ratified it in 1954. So when John Howard says at a political level `hey this is a George Bush problem, this is a Tony Blair problem, but it's not a Howard Government problem', he should read the text of the III Geneva Convention which says that it's an Australian legal responsibility.

speech.para: No country is squeaky clean on human rights but it is important that we go for the highest common denominator, not the lowest, and ensure that our processes for dealing with prisoners of war and detainees for one reason or another are fair and just.

I still do not believe that we should have been part of the coalition that invaded Iraq. The country has had a long history of invasion and it is natural that many of the tribes that make up the Iraqi people will object to outside interference, even if they had a loathed leader. There have been many loathed leaders in the world who have been removed without the help of the US. Iraq has been a terrible mistake and now we have to disengage with the minimum hurt to either Iraq or our own forces. Then we need to look at doing the right thing by providing practical assistance when we are asked to do so.

talk.start.para: —This is the end of debate on the motion originally put by the Prime Minister on 30 March this year. The original motion, which I have a copy of here, has two parts to it. We are asked today to `take note of the paper' moved and that the following words be added to the motion `and to the Prime Minister's and the Leader of the Opposition's speeches of 30 March 2004 to the Prime Minister's motion relating to ADF personnel in and around Iraq.'

speech.para: When the Prime Minister spoke on 30 March, he let off what was really the first major shot of the election campaign which is almost upon us. What he sought to do was to drag into political debate the situation of our forces in Iraq. He sought to do that through the two parts of the motion that he originally put to this House. That motion we are debating here. That was changed because the Prime Minister did something that was quite extraordinary. There was an intended division on a motion— put forward by the member for Cowan, Mr Edwards, and seconded by the member for Lalor—that these two parts be split into two. The Prime Minister came into the House and in fact forestalled the division and agreed to these two parts being split. As far as I know, that is almost unprecedented in the history of the House.

If there had been goodwill in the first place, if this notice of motion had not been designed as a political tool to attempt to split the Australian Labor Party from its support base in the community on the question of ADF personnel in Iraq, then the Prime Minister would not have had two parts to this motion; two parts that were conjoined in the first place and not meant to be split. I think it was his intention to absolutely portray the Labor Party as not being in support of our troops in Iraq and to use that politically against the Labor Party, to use it as a mechanism to try to win favour and support in the community, and to use our military personnel as weapons in that way.

Eventually this motion was split, but it should have been two separate motions in the first place. I will read the first part of the motion. The Prime Minister gave notice that at the next day of sitting he would move that this House:

quote.para: (1) expresses its continued support for and confidence in the 850 Australian Defence Force personnel currently deployed in or around Iraq and records its deep appreciation for the outstanding professionalism they have displayed in carrying out their duties;

speech.para: That is a pretty simple, direct and straightforward contention. As Mr Edwards, the member for Cowan, later argued, there is nobody on the Labor side who would contend with any of what was said in part 1 of the motion. That is why he called for the Prime Minister to split it, because everybody on the Labor side could stand up and support that part. He argued, quite rightly, that the Prime Minister's intent to fold that into part 2, which we could not support, was in fact diabolical. He called on the Prime Minister to do a couple of things. He talked about campaign medals. Secondly, he said that the second part of the motion should be split from the first. I will read the second part so that we can see the context. It reads that this House:

quote.para: (2) is of the opinion that no elements of this contingent of Australian Defence Force personnel should be withdrawn until their respective tasks have been completed and that no arbitrary times should be set for such withdrawal.

speech.para: We know the context for the Prime Minister putting this second part forward. We know that he sought in his time-honoured fashion to identify and then exercise a wedge between the Australian Labor Party and the Australian people. He saw an opportunity to seek political advantage by utilising our military personnel, whom he had placed, on his order and the order of his government, in a situation of great and pressing danger by committing them to the war in Iraq in the first place and then continuing to have those personnel based in Iraq after the formal cessation of hostilities more than a year ago. The member for Cowan quite rightly called on the Prime Minister to split the motion. He said:

quote.para: Our troops are entitled to have motions put before this House which are designed to truly reflect the support that members of parliament on this side have for them and their families. This motion does not do that. Indeed, this motion of the Prime Minister's lets our troops down. It thrusts them into areas of policy and political division which are not of the troops' making. The Prime Minister can fix that. I call on him, in the interests of keeping our troops out of the political firing line, to do this.

speech.para: He then moved a motion to split these two parts of the Prime Minister's original notice of motion.
The Prime Minister, extraordinarily, came into the House and said that he agreed to it. He then went on to say:

quote.para: I have just come into the House and I understand that there has unexpectedly been a motion from the opposition to suspend standing orders in order to split the motion. I do not in any way want to force the opposition to vote against a generic expression of support for Australian forces. I do not.

speech.para: Why did he put it in in the first place? It was purely to seek political advantage. He was forced, under the impress of the parliamentary debate, to step back from that naked use of his motion to try to seek pure partisan political advantage.

The member for Cowan is a former member of Australia's defence forces. He was badly injured in Vietnam. He lost both legs as a result of a landmine incident there. He is someone who can speak for Australian Defence Force personnel who have been properly committed by an Australian government to serve overseas, whether or not one agrees with the context that they are committed in, no matter whether the particular war is the current war in Iraq, the previous war in the Gulf or the war in Vietnam. No matter what the context or the debate is about the rights or wrongs with regard to committing troops, the fundamental reality is that Australian troops, once committed, should be supported by the Australian people and the Australian parliament—and they have been. And the member for Cowan's point was absolutely crystal clear—this was the Prime Minister's attempt to use these troops politically. I am glad that, for once in the House, the Prime Minister could be forced into a position where he had to retreat from what was a grubby exercise in political manoeuvring. Australia's defence forces, the Australian people and the parliament deserve better than this dreadful exercise to put our troops at the very point where they become the issue, rather than the larger area of debate. It was right to split that motion.

Let me go to the broader questions of the context. The current war against Iraq has had different approaches. Labor and the coalition have taken entirely different stances with regard to whether we should be there and whether it should be prosecuted. Labor said that we should not be there, because it was not UN sanctioned, because this was a small coterie of nations joined together in a small coalition that did not have the broad support of the West—including most of the countries in Europe and, we argued, the Australian people—or of the general community of the United Nations. We also said that military adventurism in Iraq would take away our necessary concentration on the war against terror, which was real, which was pressing and which needed to be prosecuted with the greatest vigour possible, as it had been in Afghanistan. It needed to be prosecuted worldwide in defence of civilians from all of the countries of the West who are imperilled by the continuation of that very war operated by al-Qaeda and its associated organisations.

We argued, quite properly and correctly, that the adventurism of another war in Iraq would not add one jot or tittle to the solution or prosecution of the war on terror. We argued that this was, in fact, something that the Bushes—both former President Bush and the current President Bush—had taken on as a particular area of the concern for themselves and for the Republican Party. There was a determination on the part of the current President Bush to prosecute this war in Iraq come what may. He made the decision right at the start of his term, not later—not after September 11 but right at the beginning—to deal with unfinished business from the previous Gulf War. I think that was wrong. We know that there was a major debate within his administration, which was split over whether or not they should go into Iraq. I think that Colin Powell and the others who argued against it did the right thing; they put the argument that the war on terror was the chief thing that should be pursued and that defence personnel should not have their lives put at risk not only in the initial phases of a war but in what might happen afterwards.

What we are seeing now is what was predicted by some people at the time; that is, that winning the war in Iraq was the easy part. Afterwards, we have the occupation by those powers which have a responsibility for what happens there—Australia being one of those, Britain another and the United States another. The occupying powers have a specific set of things that they have to do. They have to look after the local civilians, and they have to ensure that all of the normal provisions of food, education and health are seen to.

We have a situation now where there is no-one but the occupying powers with that impress on them—the United Nations did not stay—and we have had another war develop after the full conclusion of hostilities. We have got a significant problem because we have a small number of Australian personnel currently there—not the SAS, who were pulled out almost immediately after the war was signalled to have finished over a year ago—who are there to guard our people in the embassies, to train people in the Iraqi police and defence forces, and to protect those Australians who are teaching others how to do air traffic control and so on. I know how effective those Australian troops have been. One of my neighbours was one of the people from Foreign Affairs stationed in Baghdad from the beginning; he is now home. I have heard from him just how effective those forces have been.

We also know that there is a great morass in Iraq. What stood in front of Colin Powell and George Bush Snr at the end of the Gulf War—the prospect that if they went through to Baghdad and took out the existing regime there could be a civil war in Iraq—is clearer and more apparent than it was a year ago, but the prospect was there strongly a year ago. That is what stopped them more than 12 years before. Our Australian troops are in an unenviable situation in Iraq. They are there and they continue to need our support, and they have that support from the Labor Party and the Australian people. They should not be put in a position, as the Prime Minister sought to put them in on 30 March, where the level of danger that they face increased, making them a more pointed target for those people who might seek to destroy them in order to make a political point the other way. Our troops should be above and beyond being taken up in the maelstrom of Australian politics. The Prime Minister should not have attempted to use them for political purposes on 30 March. The splitting of the motion was right. They should continue to have our support without political edge. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Our troops in and around Iraq are, as always, doing a very important job, a very good job, as some of the best trained and best disciplined troops anywhere in the world. Unfortunately, though, they should not have been called upon to undertake this task. The battle in Iraq today is no longer a battle simply of guns, missiles and tanks; the battle in Iraq today is a fight for the hearts and minds of the Iraqi people—and, in that, America and its allies have lost the battle. In view of the recent photographs of mistreatment of Iraqi prisoners, I suspect that that is irrevocably lost and that it would not be possible to establish the confidence of the people necessary to win what is now a battle for the hearts and minds of the people in the streets and in the villages.

speech.para: Worse, there is now evidence that al-Qaeda has a foothold in Iraq and is cultivating some of the uprisings, a fact that did not exist before the invasion. Let there be no mistake: as bad and abhorrent a dictator as Saddam Hussein was, he was not a religious fundamentalist with links to al-Qaeda or any similar group. I have no doubt that, had members of al-Qaeda put their heads inside Saddam Hussein's Iraq, he would have very quickly put them up against a wall. There was no love lost at all between Saddam Hussein and those involved in al-Qaeda, including Osama bin Laden. Indeed, there is evidence of animosity between them.

Instead of being seen as liberators, the United States and its allies are now seen as occupiers by the Iraqi people. That is not a position from which we can build a nation. It is not a position from which we can obtain the trust of peoples in order to establish any coherent society. It is now even more important that America take a step backwards, moving back from its position of control and confrontation in Iraq, and ensure that the United Nations is given a much greater role not just in the conduct on the ground but in the broader management of affairs in Iraq.

The justification for the invasion of Iraq was not based on some lasting high principle but on varying political exigencies. We were told originally that there were weapons of mass destruction and that this presented a clear and present danger to the Western world—12 months after the war has ended, there is not a shred of evidence to support that. As that became clearer throughout the conflict, the United States and its allies changed their rhetoric—including our own Prime Minister and foreign affairs minister—from one of removing weapons of mass destruction to one of regime change and, then, as the political mood shifted again, to one of providing freedom to an oppressed population.

The justification for this invasion has been false from the beginning. As a party to this invasion, Australia has made one of the worst strategic mistakes that I think has been made since the end of the Second World War. It is high time that we refocused our efforts directly on the war on terror and removed ourselves from this terrible conflict in Iraq that has caused instability in the region and worsened global security.

These are not views of hindsight. The first occasion this parliament had to discuss this matter was in February 2003. I, along with a number of people, sounded the warning of these problems at that time—as similar warnings were being sounded in the United States and the United Kingdom. I want to refer to some of the comments I made in February of last year—well before the conflict had started—identifying these very problems. I quoted at the time the views of General Zinni, a very senior ranking officer of the United States forces. He said:

quote.para: You could inherit the country of Iraq, if you're willing to do it—if our economy is so great that you're willing to put billions of dollars into reforming Iraq. If you want to fight with other countries in the region to try to keep Iraq together as Kurds and Shiites try and split off, you're going to have to make a good case for that.

speech.para: Unfortunately, General Zinni's views, with which I strongly agreed, have proven to be the case. America and, by implication, those who joined in the invasion have now inherited a country of some 20 million people who do not want our patronage. Any doubt about that should be dispelled by a cursory look at the evening news. In my speech I also referred to the views of another highly decorated US general, General Clark, who told the US Senate Armed Services Committee that war with Iraq would `supercharge' recruiting for al-Qaeda. General Clark was right in his predictions about that—predictions he made well before the war commenced, predictions I referred to in a speech to this parliament in February of last year. Now we see, sadly, those predictions coming true as al-Qaeda feed upon the discontent to recruit more to their cause of extremism.
I made this comment in this parliament more than a year ago:

quote.para: ... were this war on Iraq to occur in the current circumstances, it would undermine rather than support the war on terror. Security would almost certainly be worse in many nations, including Australia. Any hope of resolving the underlying causes of terrorism and overcoming the factors that extremists feed upon as they seek to recruit future terrorists would be dashed.

speech.para: Sadly, those words I mentioned some 14 months ago are now coming back to haunt us as the global security environment degrades week after week and as terrorist threats increase week after week. We now find ourselves in the situation of being advised against travelling to Greece for the Olympics, because even in Greece there are concerns about terrorist activity.

The world is a much less secure place because of the invasion of Iraq than it was before the invasion of Iraq. This has been one of the great strategic errors of the last 50 years. I commented on 5 February last year in this parliament:

quote.para: It is far too simplistic to equate the war on terror with war against Iraq. Worse, it is wrong ... The world should not be sidetracked into a debate about the virtues of Saddam Hussein's Iraq at the expense of the war on terror. Nor should we focus diplomatic and military efforts on Iraq at the expense of the war on terror.

speech.para: That is even more the case today than it was when I said those words in February last year. It is a sad case that many Liberals whom I discuss this with in forums where this issue comes up regularly say, `We can't change the past. Let's not talk about the past. Let's move on and see what we can do to fix the problem.' I agree that we have to look at what we can do to fix the problem. But let us be clear about this: the reason Liberals do not want to talk about what happened last year is that they now know they were absolutely wrong. Whether they were wrong by conviction or wrong by stupidity is irrelevant; they were wrong and they committed our country to a war of invasion that we should not have participated in. Today we have Australian troops in an area of high threat who should not be there. Worse, as a result of the government's folly—as a result of their willingness to follow unquestioningly the views of the American administration—we are now in a situation where our national security has been disadvantaged and where global security is much worse than it was before—and, indeed, than it should be.

It is past the time when we need to be fair dinkum about two things. We need to be clear about honestly approaching the problems in the Middle East, which go well beyond the borders of Iraq and involve a long-term and viable solution to agreed boundaries for the states of Israel and Palestine. We also have to be clear that the problems in Iraq are not going to be solved by guns, tanks and missiles. There has to be an economic and a political solution to the problems in Iraq and, sadly, America is ill equipped to provide that. In real dollars—that is, adjusted after inflation—America has already committed more money to Iraq than was spent on the entire Marshall Plan to rebuild Europe. That is a frightening statistic. Europe after World War II was rebuilt at a lower cost than the cost of the war in, and reconstruction of, Iraq so far. The cost in Iraq to date is just the tip of the iceberg, and, while that is a cost to America primarily, other countries are being asked to share it. And for what?

In Afghanistan we still have, by all reports, al-Qaeda cells operating at will in the provinces, with war lords still linked to those terrorist groups. Even within the capital, Kabul, there are regular terrorist attacks and there have been a number of assassination attempts on the president. Even in the capital city security is threatened. People have forgotten the problems in Afghanistan. We were right to go to Afghanistan; I supported the Australian deployment in Afghanistan. There was within the borders of that state another terrorist state that had no regard for the life of people around the world. I had no difficulty whatsoever in wholeheartedly supporting our deployment there. I regret that America and many of its allies have now turned their backs on the problems in Afghanistan, thrown the ball to Europe and said to the European members of NATO, `You can now try to fix up the problems in Afghanistan and get order there.'

How much better would it be if America had 100,000 troops in Afghanistan today instead of having sent 200,000 troops to Iraq? I put it to you and to the people of Australia that both the region and the world would be much more secure if there were a secure and stable government in Afghanistan, free of the impact of the tribal leaders and the al-Qaeda operatives who still function within Afghanistan, largely as they please. How much better would it be if we had focused our diplomatic, economic, military and intelligence-gathering attention on the problems closer to home—the difficulties that we confront in our region with Jemaah Islamiah? I have already mentioned the issue of al-Qaeda in Afghanistan but we also need to remember that in a sense these organisations function like international crime: they need the money to fund the things they are doing. How much better would it be if our attention had been focused on those who finance terror—on those who fund the extremists who preach violence in their schools and in other locations? We have dropped the ball as a country. America has dropped the ball as the leader of the world in dealing with this war on terror, to pick up a misguided whim of George Bush Jnr, slavishly followed by John Winston Howard, and we are all now paying a heavy price for that. Our troops in the Middle East are called upon to pay a heavier price than the rest of us because their daily lives are threatened by their deployment in those regions.

Modern terrorism pays no regard to geography. The prospect of a traditional nation versus nation war is remote, and we are all pleased that that is the case. But when we look at the threat that we face today from non-state terrorism we realise that someone could be trained in Afghanistan today and undertake acts of terror in Spain, in our country or anywhere else in the world just as easily as someone could be trained in a terrorist camp in Asia and undertake deeds of violence in Europe, America or anywhere else. Geography is of no consequence in this. We need a global response to this threat, and that global response must include a military and strategic response. However, the war on terror will never be won by military means alone. The war on terror requires that there be economic and diplomatic measures to deal with the underlying causes—the reasons that people are recruited to do these violent acts. That has to be addressed, and precious little has been focused on that. What if some of the billions—I understand that the American Congress is approving $US1 billion a week for the war on terror—had gone to address the underlying economic and social concerns that allow these extremists to cultivate young people? Surely it is time that we took a rational approach to this. In Australia it is time that we analysed our national security interests according to Australia's needs, not George W. Bush's needs. Very often Australia's and America's needs will coincide, but when they do not we need a government that recognises that we are not the deputy sheriff of the United States. At the moment we have a Prime Minister who thinks that he is. I hope that at the next election that changes and that we get a Prime Minister who is a proud Australian.
Debate (on motion by Mr Prosser) adjourned.

motion.para: That the Main Committee do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: —The Howard government is threatening to end one of the most important environmental programs in Tasmania's history. The program is the Private Forest Reserve Program, which was formed to protect 100,000 hectares of private forest reserve in Tasmania. When the agreement was signed in 1997 by the Howard and Rundle Liberal governments, it was agreed that the program would receive $30 million in federal funding. The $30 million was broken down into two components: $20 million was committed from Tasmania's share of the National Heritage Trust and $10 million from other sources. The $10 million was transferred to the Tasmanian trust fund at the start of the program, and the money and interest earned were to be used for the program's running costs. The major proportion of the PFRP funding was the $20 million from the NHT. This was to be held in Canberra and transferred at quarterly intervals to Tasmania to pay landowners for direct costs associated with their signing perpetual covenants. I fear the Howard government is threatening to take back the $9 million remaining of the original $20 million. This would brutally end this important environmental program.

speech.para: The initial time frame for the Private Forest Reserve Program to distribute the $20 million to landowners signing perpetual covenants was by July 2002. This was unrealistic, as many factors such as all statutory agreements, advisory bodies and approval processes needed to be developed. Teams of people including biologists, administrative clerks and negotiators had to be recruited and trained; and, on top of creating a whole new program, delays were also encountered by the necessary accountability requirements put in place by the federal government. As a result there was a significant delay in starting the PFRP. In addition, there was reluctance by property owners to take up the program offer, as the federal government had neglected to change the capital gains tax rules and Centrelink income rulings. Long-term lobbying saw these serious impediments overcome in 2001 for capital gains and in 2003 for Centrelink and the deeming of income. I am happy to say that I was able to play a part in securing these changes. The program is now proceeding as planned and on track with its 2001 business plan endorsed by the federal government. It has secured protection in perpetuity of 27,641 hectares of important native forest and private land.

On 31 May 2002 the federal environment minister granted an extension of the time frame for the expenditure of the $20 million NHT component of the PFRP funding, to 30 June 2004. This extension was given on the proviso that specific improvements to the program were made. These improvements have been made, as indeed requested. In June 2003 the federal government advised that it was in their interests to transfer the remainder of the $20 million from the NHT—an amount of $9,914,052—to the Tasmanian trust fund. Unfortunately, the Commonwealth forced the inclusion of clause 6.2, which stipulated that if the funds were not expended by 30 June 2004, the money was to be returned to the Commonwealth. The Commonwealth insisted on this clause and, as such, the state had to agree.

In December 2003 and again in April 2004 the Tasmanian ministers for the environment wrote to the Hon. David Kemp, requesting an extension to this deadline. No response has yet been received to either of these urgent requests or to my letter of 27 April 2004. Why is this? As of 10 March 2004, the remaining NHT component of this funding was $8,892,562, a considerable amount. Ironically the Howard government have announced a further $350 million in funding in their 2004-05 budget, yet they appear set to revoke funds already allocated. This is truly giving with one hand and taking with the other. The Howard government need to extend the deadline for the Private Forest Reserve Program, preferably to 2010, to allow realistic time frames for the expenditure of the remaining NHT funding. This would allow this important environmental program to protect a further 40,000 hectares of under-reserve forest in Tasmania. Due to the fast-approaching deadline for the withdrawal of the previously allocated NHT funding, I hope the environment minister will respond to both my letter and the Tasmanian environment ministers' letters with haste.

subdebateinfo.title: Ryan Electorate: Centenary State High School

talk.start.para: —In April I had the opportunity to represent the federal Minister for Education, Science and Training, the Hon. Dr Brendan Nelson, at a terrific new local school in my electorate, Centenary State High School. It was a great opportunity for me and a terrific day for the school as they opened a new general learning area block worth some $1.45 million.

speech.para: The federal government funding that contributed to this building is going to make a terrific difference and add to the school's world-class facilities. The capital works project was entirely funded by the federal government, notwithstanding the suggestion by Labor members and the Labor government of Queensland, through the local member in the local press, that they made a contribution to this project. That certainly was not the case.
These state of the art facilities are exceptional and will provide a wonderful environment for the local students and contribute to their learning and being able to realise their potential.

I take the opportunity in the parliament to acknowledge the fantastic work of the principal, Mick Mickleburg—and his deputy and current acting principal, Dallas Miller. The administration and leadership of the school makes a difference. They provide wonderful leadership and an environment in which the students of Centenary State High School can reach their potential.

Centenary State High School also has a great reputation in the local community. The school's facilities are used by a large number of community organisations. I want to acknowledge that the school allows this very generously. The new learning block for the Centenary State High School is a facility that I am sure the local community will also be able to use. It will be for more than just students.

I also had the opportunity of using the facilities of the school last month when I hosted the inaugural Ryan youth leadership and development forum. To be able to bring 150 students from throughout the Ryan electorate to Centenary State High School was a great pleasure for me. It also again highlighted the local school to the rest of the Ryan community.

All schools are doing very well under the Howard government. In every budget of the Howard government since our election in 1996 grants to every state and territory have increased. Funding for schooling has increased substantially and in Queensland the Australian government funding for state schools in 2004-05 will total almost $530 million, a 4.5 per cent increase over the past year. In this year's federal budget the government have allocated record funds of $7.6 billion to Australian schools for 2004-05. This is unprecedented funding for schools and continues the trend over the last seven or eight years of Howard government budgets giving tremendous recognition to education and opportunities to students throughout the country to realise their potential.

I want to pay tribute to all those in the country whose lives are dedicated to our young people and who make a contribution by giving opportunities to our young Australians. Those people work to create an environment that will help young people to make a great contribution to our country in the future. Schools throughout the country, both public and private, are dedicated to doing this. It is important that all members of parliament represent all schools throughout the country, not just one sector of the schooling community. There seems to be a lot of emphasis on public schools. That is certainly not entirely appropriate. Schools, both private and public, should have the full support of this parliament.

Labor's rhetoric and attacks on the coalition's record on schools are hollow politics. The people of Ryan should be aware that this is not acceptable. I will certainly be conveying to the Ryan community, and the many parents who send their children to the substantial number of independent schools in the Ryan electorate, the policy differences between the government and the opposition. I am sure that come election time they will be asking very tough questions and wanting answers on these issues. Let me pay tribute to the Centenary State High School for the work that they are doing in the local community.

talk.start.para: —I wish to use this opportunity to raise the human rights of Mordechai Vanunu, the whistleblower who exposed Israel's nuclear program in the 1980s and who was recently released from prison after serving 18 years. The Vanunu family migrated to Israel in 1963. Mordechai Vanunu was a good Israeli citizen who served his time in the Israeli army. He then went on to study philosophy and worked for 10 years as a mid-level technician at Machon 2, a top-secret underground bunker complex at Dimona in the Negev Desert, which built components for nuclear weapons. Vanunu expressed dissent as to what was occurring there. He was given a warning, and then in November 1986 he was made redundant. He took with him photographs of the inside of the factory.

speech.para: He became a backpacker and travelled through Asia down to Australia, where he became associated with Australians at the St John's church in Darlinghurst and met Reverend David Smith—a friend of mine and former Marrickville citizen of the year who is known as `Fighting Father Dave', who serves at Dulwich Hill. Vanunu then travelled to London and gave his story to the Sunday Times. In Leicester Square he met an American woman, `Cindy', who befriended him and persuaded him to travel with her to Rome. It turned out that she was a Mossad agent, and whilst in Rome on 30 September 1986 Vanunu was overpowered, assaulted, drugged, kidnapped and smuggled back to Israel unconscious on a boat. He was brought to court for a secret trial. Israel had maintained a policy of nuclear ambiguity, neither confirming nor denying that it possessed nuclear weapons. It was protected from scrutiny by the United States and its allies. Vanunu's evidence showed the world that Israel had developed between 100 and 200 atomic bombs and had gone on to develop neutron bombs and thermonuclear weapons.

He was found guilty of treason and espionage and sentenced to 18 years imprisonment, served at a prison in the southern Israeli town of Ashkalon. He was held in solitary confinement for 11½ years. His cell was six feet by nine feet with no windows. His request for parole was denied at least six times, but he was finally released on 21 April this year. However, his punishment continues. Avraham Poraz, Israel's minister of the interior, has issued an order forbidding Vanunu from leaving the country for one year after his release. Also, Major General Yair Naveh, head of the Home Front Command of the Israel Defense Forces, citing quite extraordinarily the Defence (Emergency) Regulations from the British mandate period of 1946 prior to the formation of Israel which were subsequently incorporated into Israeli law, has ordered Vanunu not to speak with anyone about his employment within the Dimona program. He is also prohibited from approaching foreign embassies or consulates or conversing with non-Israelis. These restrictions are in force for six months and are renewable. Vanunu's lawyers are contesting these restrictions, which were provided for when Vanunu was originally tried and punished. This is a fundamental violation of due process. In support of these new restrictions, Israeli officials have cited national security concerns, but who could believe that information held by a junior technician 18 years ago continues to be relevant?

The double standards in this are astonishing. At a time when the world has gone to war over weapons of mass destruction, this individual was jailed for 18 years and held in solitary confinement for 11 years for exposing the reality of weapons of mass destruction being held in Israel. It is believed today that Israel has the world's sixth largest nuclear arsenal, with small tactical nuclear weapons, nuclear landmines and medium-range nuclear missiles launchable from air, land or sea. It is quite clear that Mr Vanunu is not safe where he is at the moment. This is not a sectarian issue. This should be of concern to all those who have an interest in nuclear nonproliferation. Israel is one of the three countries in the world that have refused to sign up to the nonproliferation treaty. It is important that all people of goodwill, apart from sectarian issues, defend Mr Vanunu's human rights. I congratulate Reverend Dave Smith and will be working with him to ensure that those rights are upheld.

talk.start.para: —A nation can expect no higher individual commitment from its citizens than to serve their country in a time of war and conflict. The recent Anzac Day services across our country and in all of our electorates reminded us of the strong commitment to and the sacrifice for the ideals and the freedoms that we all hold so strongly. Anzac Day keeps the memory of Gallipoli and the First World War alive so that younger generations know of the sacrifice and can keep that spirit alive.

speech.para: But of course Anzac Day is also very much about the men and women who served Australia in some of the important conflicts that followed the First World War to protect those same values and freedoms. It is worth reminding ourselves constantly of the sheer number of Australians who served our nation in times of need. In the Second World War, 990,000 men and women served in various capacities in our services. In the Army, just over 26,000 lost their lives; just over 2,000 in the Navy; and 11,000 in the RAAF. More than 66,000 Australians were wounded in the Second World War. In Korea, 17,000 served, 339 lost their lives, more than 1,200 were wounded and 29 were taken as prisoners of war. In Vietnam, 42,000 served in the Army, almost 3,000 served in the Navy and 4½ thousand served in the RAAF. As we know, 520 were killed and 2½ thousand were wounded.

Like all members in the chamber, I was once again privileged to attend Anzac Day ceremonies. I attended ceremonies in Croydon, Lilydale and Monbulk. The dawn service in Lilydale had a huge crowd, as did the service later in the morning in Monbulk. On the day, many people, including many radio commentators and those in the media, expressed surprise that the crowds were still so large on what we all recall was a very wet and wintry day. But really this should be no surprise at all—just confirmation that Australians hold their beliefs strongly. They attend these services because of their enduring and unshakeable commitment, and nothing will keep them away.

The work that goes on in preparing for Anzac Day is often overlooked because of the focus on the day itself. In the brief time available to me, I would like to pay tribute to some of the many dedicated RSL members who work tirelessly each year selling Anzac Day badges and selling poppies before Remembrance Day. All of the funds are used in the RSL's welfare work. Many contribute right across the electorate and right across Australia, but I would particularly like to pay tribute to Mr Frank Voutier of the Croydon RSL. Each year he visits hundreds of Melbourne's businesses in the outer east. He also visits schools and community groups and sets himself up in the local shopping malls to sell as many Anzac Day badges and poppies as he possibly can. He has become a feature of the Croydon community and pretty much owns Main Street, Croydon, in the weeks leading up to Anzac Day, with his self-made badge display, where he sells badges to all and sundry.

The magnitude and dedication of his work and the work of many others who assist him in that area saw the Croydon RSL receive the status of the top Victorian sub-branch for sales in the 2003 Poppy Appeal, where they raised nearly $30,000 single-handedly. The Australian community needs its Frank Voutiers, and we are fortunate that there are so many like him across the country in all of our electorates, doggedly building and preserving that Anzac spirit. Their dedication to our nation in times of war and conflict is of course matched by an identical dedication to the welfare of the veterans and the communities in which they live. We must never forget their sacrifices. On behalf of the outer east and the Yarra Valley, I wish to publicly recognise Frank's efforts and those of so many who assist him not just on Anzac Day but throughout the entire year.

talk.start.para: —I want to raise today in the parliament an important issue relating to a key agricultural industry. As you and other Tasmanians would know, Mr Deputy Speaker Adams, the federal government is revisiting the plan of allowing apples from New Zealand to come into Australia. This is something it has had a real agenda on for some time, causing an enormous amount of concern in the apple and pear industry in Australia, an industry which has been a great contributor to rural and regional Australia over many years. There is a long history to this issue. I am sure members of this House can remember that in the year 2000 Biosecurity Australia published a draft import risk assessment promoting and suggesting the importation of New Zealand apples. The draft proposed that New Zealand apples be allowed into Australia, which caused an enormous amount of concern. In 1998 AQIS first had a look at this issue. Before that, as you, Mr Deputy Speaker, and other people with an interest in this issue would know, the case for allowing New Zealand apples into Australia had been made in 1989 and was rejected by the Labor government. Previously, right back in 1921, the case had been made by New Zealand to allow their apples into Australia. Because of the risk of fire blight, the government then took the view that that should not be allowed.

speech.para: My real concern is that all of this sneaky behaviour on behalf of those people pushing for the importation of New Zealand apples into Australia has caused a great deal of uncertainty for apple and pear growers in Australia. The handling of this issue by the federal government is a textbook example of poor public policy and poor public administration by government. What we have seen over six or seven years is the federal government being incapable of making a decision in Australia's national interest when it comes to this issue. We should have a government that stands up and defends Australia. We should have a government that is proud to protect the interests of apple and pear growers in Australia—not a government that uses its agencies in order to promote the interests of apple and pear growers from a foreign country. We need to see some action from the federal government to decisively indicate to ordinary people in Australia who run these apple and pear orchards that it will not sell out their interests to New Zealand.

You, Mr Deputy Speaker, and the other Tasmanians in this parliament understand just how hard ordinary apple and pear growers work. In many cases they are the second and third generation of people on those orchards. Why is it that the Howard government does not stand up for these people who have contributed so much to the rural and regional areas in which they operate for so many years, in some cases for a number of generations? Why is it that we do not have a government that is prepared to take a stance on this issue in Australia's national interest? Why is it that we do not have Liberal and Nationals members opposite standing up in this parliament and advocating on behalf of these hardworking small business owners who have made such an important contribution? They work hard all their lives and pay taxes all their lives and have contributed so much to our national economy. I say to the parliament today that enough is enough in relation to this issue. We have seen the hardworking apple and pear growers of Australia have to put up with delays, changed processes, obfuscation and failure to make a decision from the Howard government for too long.

Enough is enough. These people should be focusing on their businesses. That is what they do best. They do not want to have to spend a third to a half of their time every week in lobbying the Australian government to stand up for Australia's national interest. That should be automatic. We should have a government in Australia that stands up for Australia's national interests and that understands and recognises the fundamental truth that bringing fire blight apples into Australia would be an absolute disaster for the apple and pear industry in this country. I say to the Howard government: stop sitting on your hands in relation to this issue; stand up for Australia's national interest and ban the importation of New Zealand apples into this country.

talk.start.para: —Cancer is a huge burden on our society. It is responsible for nearly 20 per cent of deaths and disabilities in this country. Around 34,000 Australians die from cancer each year. According to figures from the Bureau of Statistics, cancer is the most common cause of death in Australia. From the government's perspective, it takes up about six per cent of the national health budget. Australia is one of the few countries in the world where cancer mortality is actually falling for both men and women. In fact, the survival rate for many common cancers has increased by more than 30 per cent in the past two decades. The federal coalition government has played an important part in this statistic and has a strong record in developing and implementing effective cancer control measures.

speech.para: In our first year in office in 1996, we took the proactive step of making cancer control a national health priority, and we created a framework for a national cancer control plan. The following year, we established a national cancer control initiative to provide expert advice on all issues relating to cancer control. One of the strengths of this initiative is a partnership with the Cancer Council Australia, which has taken a strong lead in the fight against cancer at the community level since the 1960s. Representatives of the Cancer Council recently approached me with a practical plan for the government which would potentially save thousands of lives and millions of health dollars. The Cancer Council Australia and the Clinical Oncological Society of Australia have put forward a very strong case for a $5 million investment in infrastructure funding for cancer clinical trial groups. Based on the success of previous clinical trials, a $5 million investment could generate returns of tens of millions of health dollars each year. This type of investment stands to save thousands of Australian lives and reduce the suffering and premature disability associated with some cancers.
