Clinical trials are the only reliable scientific method of testing whether treatments such as drugs, surgical procedures and radiotherapy work; whether one treatment is better than another; how to integrate treatments better; whether new treatments are better than older treatments; and, for treatments of equivalent effectiveness, determining which treatments cause fewer side effects and provide better value for money. Clinical trial groups have generated a number of remarkable successes, both in Australia and abroad. For example, studies in advanced breast cancer found that a high-dose chemotherapy with bone marrow transplantation was no better than a standard dose of chemotherapy. The estimated cost saving is $50,000 per patient—a total saving of around $50 million each year—and up to 1,000 patients a year will no longer have to endure an arduous, high-dose treatment.

An Australian trial in testicular cancer, the most common cancer in young men, found that one type of chemotherapy cured more patients and saved more lives than another; yet before the trial the two treatments were considered equally effective. Clinical trials also help to ensure that expensive new treatments are introduced in a careful, informed way, based on sound evidence and quality control. The Cancer Council puts a strong case in arguing the government's need to fund infrastructure for clinical trials through a respected community partner such as the Cancer Council Australia.

While the pharmaceutical industry conducts its own product related trials, I believe the government has a clear role in ensuring that trials are conducted which consider cancer treatments without a commercial motive. The Cancer Council Australia has a proud history of working cooperatively with government to help put the needs of the community first. I believe that the Cancer Council Australia would help to guarantee that clinical trials focus exclusively on the broader health gains of this important part of the fight against cancer. I would like to place on the public record my support for the Cancer Council's clinical trials and my endorsement of Cancer Council Australia's case for a $5 million investment in clinical trial infrastructure funding. On the advice I have received from the Cancer Council Australia I believe that additional support for Cancer Council clinical trials infrastructure funding would have significant short-term and long-term economic and health benefits for all of Australia.

talk.start.para: —In 1993 the then federal Labor government's decision to give favourable consideration to a recommendation of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure ensured a sixth high-power national television channel was made available for community access. Eleven years later, I bring to the attention of the parliament the current crisis in community television and the shameful way Community Television Sydney, the current operators of Channel 31, have been treated by the Australian Broadcasting Authority and their masters—the Howard government.

speech.para: For 11 years CTS has provided local and international news, information and entertainment programs to Australians of non-English-speaking backgrounds, including the Italian, Greek, Lebanese, Chinese, Vietnamese, Tamil, Indian and Croatian communities in my electorate of Lowe and across Sydney on Australia's sixth free-to-air channel, Channel 31. After 11 years of successful operation, reaching over 1.3 million people every month in Sydney alone, the ABA has decided not to renew the temporary licence of CTS but instead to award a permanent licence to another, less experienced, provider, Television Sydney—TVS.

There are at least two important issues concerning the way in which CTS was treated which can only be described as grossly unfair. The first is the absurd length of time the ABA took to finally make its decision to grant a permanent licence. The second is that, having made the decision to disregard the application from CTS and grant the permanent licence to TVS—a consortium that I understand will not be ready to broadcast until 2005 at the earliest—neither the ABA nor the Howard government have indicated whether or not CTS will be allowed to at least continue broadcasting until TVS is ready. This would obviously be in the public interest and in the interests of the CTS staff, program providers, volunteer networks and other stakeholders.

When my constituent Mr Salvatore Scevola, an important program provider of the Italian Television Network which broadcasts on Channel 31, approached me earlier this year informing me that the ABA had been investigating the granting of a permanent licence to CTS for over two years and that Channel 31's temporary licence was about to expire in just over two weeks, I was furious and determined to take the fight to the government on behalf of Mr Scevola. I immediately asked the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts question No. 3270 appearing on the Notice Paper on 4 March this year to expedite the granting of a permanent licence to CTS. I also made representations to the ABA chair, Professor David Flint, to have CTS granted the permanent licence—to no avail.

We now know the permanent licence has gone to Television Sydney, but I want the minister for communications to explain why the ABA abandoned CTS after 11 years and overlooked their submission for a permanent licence, ignoring more than 200 letters of support, including letters from numerous members of the government's own backbench. I have also asked the minister for communications another question, No. 3443, calling on him to explain why the ABA awarded the permanent licence to TVS when their proposed programming schedule reveals that they only intend to provide 3½ hours of ethnic community broadcasting per week—nowhere near the 18 hours per week currently being provided by CTS. Even worse, it appears that the new licensee, TVS, will not be able to broadcast before 2005, which breaches the ABA's guidelines under subsection (2) of section 84 of the Broadcasting Services Act 1992.

The minister for communications needs to explain what the programmers at CTS, the sponsors who support community television and the 1.3 million viewers of Channel 31 in Sydney are supposed to do for the next eight months. It is clear that the Howard government is not interested in these viewers or anyone who supports community television. This may surprise some people, but it does not surprise me and it does not surprise the people in my electorate of Lowe, who understand and are outraged by the appalling way the Howard government is prepared to reward Australia's most powerful media owners at the expense of our democracy by ripping up Australia's cross-media laws through the Broadcasting Services Amendment (Media Ownership) Bill 2002, which is in the Senate at the moment. The Howard government's proposed media laws will allow the largest media owners to own television stations and newspapers in the same city. This will mean fewer journalists and fewer opinions, and it will damage Australia's democracy.

In conclusion, given the Howard government's media policies and its failure to promote media diversity in Australia, its contempt for CTS and Channel 31 is tragically predictable. However, I know Mr Salvatore Scevola will not give up; I know CTS will not give up; and I know the people who support community television in my electorate of Lowe and across Sydney will not give up. And I am sure they look forward to the opportunity to sack the Howard government when the federal election is held later this year.

talk.start.para: —I would like to congratulate Brisbane's new Lord Mayor, Campbell Newman, whose outstanding victory recently in the local government elections was an overwhelming victory for the people of Brisbane and for accountability in local government. That accountability, sadly, was missing under the previous Labor civic administration. Campbell Newman stands for what the people of Brisbane overwhelmingly voted for: a city hall that listens to them, consults them, treats them with honesty and respect and puts their quality of life before Labor Party factional or financial interests. Anyone who doubts how Labor ran things in Brisbane should look at the example of a neighbourhood group in my electorate who fought the previous Labor city hall administration and the state government that ran it.

speech.para: Last year, the Remick Bushland Preservation Group were fighting to save six hectares of native vegetation that was used and cared for by locals as a community open green space. The land is owned by the state government, which lodged a development application to council against the wishes of the local community. The community fought back, forcing the state government to withdraw its development application from council. The state government then played a game of payback by threatening to sell to a private developer instead. The group wrote to me, quoting the state government's ominous `inference that as a consequence we would suffer a development “far less favourable” than the development by the state government'. Is it any wonder that that ward recently went to a Liberal candidate? Before the election, the candidate took up this issue with the community and with the sitting state Labor member, Terry Sullivan. His only response was to ask how the community, through council, would fund a buyback from the state government. On its web site the Beattie government claims to recognise:

motion.para: That public spaces and natural landscapes make an enormous contribution to the social, cultural, spiritual and environmental health of our community.
That having access to natural environments adds significantly to the quality of life of all Queenslanders who live in an increasingly urbanised society ...
Empower communities and secure solid partnerships with local government and regional communities ...

speech.para: I call on the Queensland government to live up to those fine words—and they are fine words on that web site—and to hand over the Remick Street bushland preserve to the Brisbane City Council to be held in trust for the local community.

I would also like to place on the record my appreciation of the Prime Minister's recent announcement of the $20 million community crime prevention initiatives in our local communities around Australia. This is an investment not only in the security and safety of ordinary Australians but also in the peace of mind of those who are most vulnerable in society. Community organisations are the logical place to tackle the increasing problems of vandalism and petty crime on our quality of life. No-one is better placed to fund long-term solutions than those grassroots organisations.

In my electorate of Petrie I am no stranger to the problem. I know from first-hand experience the frustration, inconvenience and expense caused by petty crime like vandalism. A more unlikely setting for it is very hard to find than the wonderful environment of my electorate office on the Redcliffe waterfront, where the blue waters of Moreton Bay lap against a palm-fringed lagoon straight out of a holiday brochure. But over the past two months, like all businesses fronting this wonderful panoramic view of the bay, my office has been the subject of repeated vandal attacks which have shattered every plate glass window in every pub, cafe and small business. And no sooner is the glass replaced than it is smashed again. The inconvenience and the economic impact are pretty self-evident.

Less visible, though, but even more damaging is the way in which fear spreads among the most vulnerable members of our community: the elderly who live alone in their homes, whose last shred of security is stripped away, who have become too scared even to indulge in the innocent pleasure of visiting shops and who fear that they will be the next victim. It is some time since I proposed a scheme to set up a community telephone network coordinating the local Neighbourhood Watch, Red Cross, Rotary and other organisations to make daily phone calls to local elderly residents living alone and to check on their security and safety. The recognition by the Australian government of the role that such a community organisation can play in protecting the vulnerable is very welcome. I look forward to helping organisations in my electorate avail themselves of this funding to ensure that the most frail members of our community, the elderly, are called each day to see whether they are okay and to ensure that they have dignity, safety and respect in their own homes.

talk.start.para: —I rise this morning to raise some very important transport infrastructure issues. In passing, I will make some comments on the Brisbane metropolitan area. I noticed that the member for Petrie referred to the recent election of a new mayor of the City of Brisbane. I simply say that infrastructure is about honesty and integrity and actually putting your plans out for proper public consideration. In the lead-up to his election the mayor promised a range of major infrastructure tunnels in Brisbane. I suggest to the House this morning that only one of those tunnels—the east-west tunnel—actually stacks up in financial terms.

speech.para: I therefore call upon the Mayor of Brisbane to release for public scrutiny all the costings which he claims to have that do not require a call on the public purse in terms of the range of tunnels he proposes be constructed in the Brisbane metropolitan area. It is about time people were forced to come clean about promises they make before the election and their capacity to actually deliver them after the election.

In that context I want to call for Australia to have a national land transport plan. I notice that the Minister for Transport and Regional Services in this week's budget finally put a date to the release of the AusLink plan: Monday, 7 June. That is interesting, especially when we were told with the release of the green paper in November 2002 that the final paper was not far down the track.

I want to raise some important questions in terms of what might be released on 7 June. I suggest to the House that the government's approach to a national land transport plan, titled AusLink, is not a constructive approach to infrastructure planning and delivery in Australia but more importantly an exercise to shift cost and responsibility onto state and local governments. This is a very serious issue because in Australia in the 21st century we are falling further and further behind on the infrastructure front—and not just in roads and bridges and access to ports and railways but also, for example, in access to the communication system.

We, first and foremost, therefore need an independent infrastructure advisory council to actually assist all levels of government in making decisions on independent objective criteria so we can take the politics out of decision making and make sure that the projects that we select are selected for the right reasons. That goes to one of my primary criticisms of the proposed AusLink plan. On numerous occasions since November 2002, and this is a national issue, the Minister for Transport and Regional Services and, in more recent times, the Minister for Local Government, Territories and Roads have said, fairly and squarely, that the government does not regard the national highway as any longer a full Commonwealth government responsibility. I want to make it clear that I believe that the Commonwealth, in terms of land transport in Australia, has a national responsibility.

Our freight task is going to double. It is not going to happen overnight. It is happening every week of the year. What we require is a system of rail and freight national opportunities for us to move that freight on in the future. That means we have to take the politics out of decision making and move away from the cherry picking of projects—as will occur under AusLink on the national highway system—and provide a guarantee that one level of government, the Commonwealth government, accepts the ongoing responsibility for maintaining and improving our national highway system.

I say today on behalf of a range of communities around Australia that an AusLink plan which does not provide for the Commonwealth to maintain a full commitment to the construction and maintenance of the national highway system is unacceptable. It is unacceptable, for example, for the people who have to use the Hume Highway. It is unacceptable to the people of Melbourne awaiting the construction of the Deer Park bypass. It is unacceptable to the people who depend on the Ipswich Motorway. It is unacceptable to the people who depend on the Bruce Highway; for example, those who saw the Bruce Highway recently cut because of flooding at Tully.

talk.start.para: —What about Scoresby?

—It is also unacceptable to the member who interjects, because his own community depends on the Commonwealth accepting responsibility for the Bruce Highway. It is also unacceptable to those in Tasmania who depend on the Bass Highway. I simply say in conclusion that infrastructure planning is about the future of Australia. Accept your responsibilities. Do not cherry pick for political reasons.

talker.name: Slipper, Peter, MP
Mr SLIPPER
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance and Administration

talk.start.para: —As the member for Fisher for more than 10 years, commemorating Anzac Day has been one of the most enjoyable activities that I, like other elected representatives, have each year. This year was no different. On Anzac Day 2004 I attended seven different commemoration services, all over the electorate. It is heartening to see the increasing crowds each year. You would have seen the increasing crowds in your own electorate, Mr Deputy Speaker Adams, particularly the numbers of young people who come out to dawn services and to the various main services. It is important to remember the fact that in this nation we have freedom, stability and a way of life that has made us the envy of people throughout the world. To go to Anzac ceremonies is to recognise the sacrifice made by so many, and the lives of so many others which were risked, in the cause of making sure that we have the free society that we do.

speech.para: The services I went to included the dawn services at both Maroochydore and Kawana. Through a strange quirk of climate, the dawn breaks a whole hour later at Kawana than Maroochydore, which meant I was able to go to both services. I went to the Buderim main service, the Caloundra main service and a lunch with the veterans at Maleny—an area which has been returned to the Fisher electorate from Longman in the recent federal redistribution—following the ceremony there. I also went to the service put on at the Centaur Memorial Nursing Home at Caloundra.

It is always humbling to talk with veterans, who have given so much to ensure that we have the way of life we do, about their wartime experiences. Perhaps the increase in attendance year by year is a recognition that the world is not a safe place and that there are new and different threats confronting our nation, particularly with the war against terror. I think that all of us recognise the wonderful role carried out by ex-servicemen and women in making our country a safer place.

When we look at the fact that today we have some 2,000 personnel deployed on more than 10 operations around the world, we see that the role being carried out by our personnel today is every bit as important as the role carried out by those who participated in world conflicts. Our personnel are involved in the rehabilitation of Iraq, the war on terror and peacekeeping missions in East Timor, the Solomon Islands and other places. They are carrying on the wonderful tradition of the Australian armed forces, protecting our way of life. On behalf of my constituents in the electorate of Fisher, I want to take this opportunity to thank all of our serving and past personnel for their contribution to our nation.

I think the continuing interest in Anzac Day commemorations is also a result of the wonderful programs being run in schools, both government and non-government, which ensure our young people learn about our heritage and the conflicts that have helped shape the Australian society that we enjoy today. A number of schools in my electorate held Anzac Day ceremonies, and I was able to attend Mountain Creek State High School, Talara Primary College and Conondale State School. I was particularly pleased to be able to distribute the Anzac Day Saluting Their Service information packs, posters and badges for students to schools throughout my electorate so that they could all use them to prepare for, and as part of, their Anzac Day commemorations.

I have been pleased to talk with many students and teachers to encourage students to take further part in Anzac Day commemorations by entering the Anzac Day Saluting Their Service awards. These awards are an initiative of the Howard government, designed to support schools in developing innovative ways to commemorate the Anzac tradition and learn about the importance of Australia's maritime heritage. I am pleased to see the member for Franklin in the chamber, because I understand that his father was an original Anzac.

talk.start.para: —That is right.

—These awards are open to all primary and secondary schools and are judged on the research undertaken, the understanding of Anzac Day and the involvement of local veterans and Australian Defence Force volunteers. I have encouraged students throughout the Sunshine Coast to participate in this particular program. It is very important that they should talk to local veterans, attend memorial services and do whatever they can to keep this wonderful tradition alive. Schools have the option to enter class or whole-of-school activities, and every school that enters will receive a certificate acknowledging their participation. The awards will be open until 28 May, and I want to encourage schools throughout the nation to fully participate in this very important initiative. More information about the program can be obtained from the Department of Veterans' Affairs web site, www.dva.gov.au.

—Today I wish to raise a matter that should concern all members in this House. I was surprised to receive representations in my office from two young Australians who have been treated shabbily by immigration authorities at Heathrow and Manchester airports in England. Many of us have unfortunately experienced the intolerable, inflexible and authoritarian attitude of immigration officials in our travels around the world. Australia has had a long and strong bond with what was once called our mother country, the United Kingdom. Prior to the formation of the EU, countries once part of the British Empire, and subsequently the British Commonwealth, were given some priority when it came to entering Britain. Now, as one enters either Heathrow or Manchester, one is shuffled to the periphery, sidelined almost as an alien. One has to justify why he or she should be allowed to enter a country our forefathers fought and died for in two world wars. As members of the coalition of the willing in the war against terrorism, and with our involvement in the war in Iraq, one would have thought that we should have some reasonable entry at any time into the United Kingdom as Australian citizens. Unfortunately, the terror paranoia that is being fostered by the US administration and implemented by the US immigration authorities is now being adopted by the UK immigration authorities.

speech.para: Vijesh Nandan, a 22-year-old Tasmanian, suspects that he was interrogated and refused entry to Britain because of his colour. VJ, as he is known to his friends, had twice been to the UK on a working visa, the last time working at a Leeds court. VJ suspects that because he looked like a potential threat to the UK he was taken aside, questioned repeatedly and body-searched, despite having sufficient money and a return air fare to Australia. VJ says:

quote.para: I kept asking why they were doing this. I thought it must be the way I look. All the people in there—

speech.para: that is, those being questioned—

quote.para: were of Asian or African or Afro-Caribbean appearance.

speech.para: VJ was detained for 15 hours, put on the next British Airways flight and had a black cross placed on his Heathrow stamp. VJ has also lost $3,000, the cost of his ticket.

A couple of days later, a 30-year-old former student of mine, Tyrone Gregs, was similarly humiliated when he reached the UK. Tyrone had worked and saved $4,000 to have a three-month visit to the United Kingdom, which was going to include attending a wedding in Scotland at which his girlfriend was to be the matron of honour. British immigration officials implied that he planned to stay and work illegally in the country. Tyrone said:

quote.para: It was just the way they treated me, like I was scum trying to slip through the system. Our diggers stood side by side with this country during the war; the Queen's head is on our money.

speech.para: Tyrone similarly was questioned. He was handcuffed and made to wait in a glass booth while passengers passed at Manchester Airport. He was deported, using his own return air fare, and, like VJ, had a black cross placed on his Heathrow stamp. I told both of these constituents that I would raise their cases with the British High Commissioner and his office. I have done that. I am waiting to see what the bloody hell has being going on. I am still waiting, as I say, for their response. I would urge all young Australians who are thinking of visiting the UK to please get a visa, or else you might never set foot outside Heathrow Airport.

It is interesting to note that I heard, as an aside, in the House yesterday that an honourable senator in the other place who had just attended the IPU conference in Mexico was similarly humiliated by American immigration authorities, despite carrying an official passport, which we members and senators are all allowed to have. She was absolutely humiliated in one of the American airports. If you would like to know what Senator Ferris thought of the whole operation of the authorities, I would urge you to go and talk to her. This paranoia of the American immigration authorities and the British immigration authorities needs to be questioned. All young Australians who are thinking of visiting the UK, for goodness sake, go and pester the British High Commissioner, Sir Alastair Goodlad, and say to him: `What is going on? I thought we were friends and partners. Do we need a visa, or can we just rock up there, with our return air fare, and expect to be humiliated, handcuffed, body-searched and then deported on the next Qantas or British Airways flight?' It is not good enough, and it has to stop.

talk.start.para: —In recent months, and in Tuesday night's budget, there has been very good news for country regions and industries, especially for the electorate of Parkes, where export industries certainly underpin the whole economy—whether that be in agriculture, mining or tourism. The one in four people directly involved in those industries are totally dependent upon export industries, yes, but also on the transport system. Transport affects whatever the inputs might be to those industries—whether it be superphosphate, grain or whatever—and also the products going out, which by and large go to ports around Australia, whether they be in Adelaide, Melbourne, Sydney or Brisbane, or south in the coal region.

speech.para: I am very proud to be part of a government that has recognised that we cannot be a potential Brazil or a potential Argentina whose infrastructures have crumbled. Certainly, in the case of Brazil, this has probably prevented the potential to far exceed and surpass what Australia does in agriculture and exports generally. The reason they have crumbled and are in the economic mess that they are in—certainly in respect of the industries to which I refer—is because their infrastructure, their transport, their road and their rail systems are totally decimated in comparison with what we are proposing to do with ours. Under John Anderson, we are virtually looking at about $11.4 billion now committed towards a road and rail infrastructure program. On Tuesday night, well over $3 billion was committed straight into Auslink to join the Roads to Recovery. Also announced on Tuesday night was $1 billion, which will largely go to regional councils for roads as well. They are mostly, and very sensibly, bypassing state governments, not allowing them to take off their 15 per cent or whatever it is they choose to take out by way of administration. Going directly to local governments, or to whatever particular scheme it might be, is certainly money saving for the Australian taxpayer. In the case of the New South Wales government, I can guarantee it is.

The industries in my electorate that are going to gain so much from this renewal of the ongoing support that is going into our roads and rail is enormous. Certainly, in New South Wales, and particularly in western New South Wales, it is more important than ever. We are expanding and extending our road funding, getting into rail and taking over the ARTC under the guise of the Commonwealth, which is taking over pretty much all national rail systems. It is taking over the New South Wales rail system in the very near future and that will get, I think, $540 million in the coming month of June to invest into New South Wales main lines because of the absolute neglect that they have had from the New South Wales government. The New South Wales government has cut back its funding on roads and rail at the same time as we are expanding and taking over those things. What we find is that the minute we fund something New South Wales cuts back on it.

But the point I make this morning is that the industries we have in western New South Wales which are expanding and developing are absolutely reliant on us maintaining and expanding our road and rail system. Because branch lines are being neglected and not being kept up, it is putting far greater pressure on the roads—mostly state, local and regional roads—and they cannot carry the traffic. So, at the same time as funding is being cut back on roads and rail, the call on them is greater than it ever was. In recent times, for example, in West Wyalong in the south of our electorate, Frank Pace and his family have opened up Pace Farms, which will be the largest egg producing centre in the Southern Hemisphere. They will call upon 200,000 tonnes of grain a year. That has got to be carried and it has got to be carried on good roads. At the moment that is not happening, not out of the state system. However, through Auslink and what we are doing at the federal level, the $11.4 billion that we are committing is certainly going to make that easier. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Sadly, I stand here today to report to the House how this government, in particular the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Transport and Regional Services and the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, have sat idly by and allowed at least two serious cases of environmental vandalism to take place at Perth airport—with a third pending. The Perth airport site contains areas of high conservation value, including significant areas of banksia woodland that are habitat to several rare flora and significant fauna species. The site also contains areas of wetland which are recognised nationally, predominantly mapped by the state as conservation category and recognised as requiring retention. A substantial part of these bushland areas has recently been cleared or drained for commercial operations not related to core activities.

speech.para: The master plan at Perth airport recognises the environmental significance of much of the areas or precincts within the airport site. There is in addition to the master plan a memorandum of understanding which was signed between the Westralia Airports Corporation, the private lessee of Perth airport, and the Western Australian state government—indeed, it was signed by Richard Court, the former Liberal Premier of Western Australia. That memorandum of understanding determines that the Westralia Airports Corporation will consult with the state department of environment on issues that would require referral or consideration by a state agency if the land was under state rather than Commonwealth control and planning laws.

In the first case I want to refer to, Commonwealth approval was given for a large area of bushland to be cleared to accommodate a warehouse development. However, this approval was given contrary to a state department of environment submission advising that the development plan would need to be modified to minimise impacts on areas of the greatest conservation values. Indeed, the Minister for Transport and Regional Services' own environmental assessment report revealed some interesting information about the proposed development. For example, it says:

quote.para: The Forestfield Bushland listing also includes most of the southern section of Precinct 2C (44 hectares in extent). In terms of the proposed development, the vast majority of this precinct will be cleared. Approximately 38 % of the precinct is covered by vegetation rated as part of the top 5% of remnant vegetation remaining within the Perth Metropolitan Region. This vegetation is found over much of Precinct 2C in both the north and east and it is difficult to see how such a large structure could be sited without significantly impacting on these values. Alternative sitings of the structure within the precinct would have similar impacts.

speech.para: It goes on to talk about the potential damage to the area and touch upon the significant Aboriginal heritage associated with much of the site. Despite this internal environmental assessment advice to Commonwealth ministers, they apparently chose not to follow the advice, to give no consideration to the opinion of the state government agencies involved, and they allowed the clearing of the whole area proposed for development. No consideration was given to recognising, let alone properly managing, this significant biodiversity area. Tragically, this has resulted in the clearing of Bush Forever and National Estate listed bushland.

The second case involved drainage maintenance work that took place at Perth airport. Drainage earthworks were carried out to enlarge and deepen an old drain to divert the waters of Poison Gully Creek. Poison Gully Creek was one of the main streams feeding the Munday Swamp, which is part of the National Estate listed area at the airport site and a designated Aboriginal heritage area. Diverting the waters of Poison Gully has the potential to seriously impact on the environmentally sensitive Munday Swamp. If the swamp dries out, it would threaten the only significant populations of two WA endemic fish species that are surviving in the Perth metropolitan area. This work was undertaken without any reference to the relevant state departments and Commonwealth agencies. Indeed, it would appear that the Westralia Airports Corporation received retrospective approval from the federal government.

This is an extraordinary situation, and one has to seriously question this government's commitment to protecting areas that are set aside for retention under Commonwealth and state regulation and legislation. The failure of Westralia Airports Corporation to honour the memorandum of understanding with the Western Australian government is high handed at best and is deliberately irresponsible. The Deputy Prime Minister should have taken action against Westralia Airports Corporation. What have the Commonwealth ministers done to address this situation? Apparently nothing. I urge them to act before the proposed take of groundwater by Westralia Airports Corporation. (Time expired)

talker.name: Entsch, Warren, MP
Mr ENTSCH
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources

talk.start.para: —Last year, the Queensland state Labor government in its wisdom decided to introduce an alcohol management plan into Cape York—a plan which was clearly designed to win votes in Brisbane and areas outside the Cape York area but which had little consideration for the impact it was going to have on Cape York communities. I will make it very clear in the first instance that alcohol is a major problem in these communities. There is no doubt about it, and the communities themselves recognise it as a major problem. The domestic violence, the dysfunctionality of families et cetera that are caused by this addiction need to be seriously addressed, but in trying to impose something like prohibition onto a community without the support of the community you are guaranteeing to have a project that is going to fail. There is no doubt about it.

speech.para: We have a situation where they imposed this prohibition without any consideration for those people up there who are already afflicted with alcohol addiction. As a consequence, one day they are alcoholics and the next day they have no access at all to alcohol—no treatment, no detoxification and no way of dealing with their problem. As a consequence, we now see in many of these communities where they cannot get grog that they are into petrol sniffing, glue sniffing and other alternatives. If they cannot access this, they are moving out of these communities and into mainstream towns like Weipa, Cooktown and even Cairns and transporting the problem with them. Of course, their actions then reflect badly on the communities they come from.

In spite of continued pleas by the various community leaders asking that they deal with the detoxification in a different way, the state government has ignored them. The stupidity of this law was seen recently when the state minister for Aboriginal affairs, the local state member and a newly elected state member travelled into an Aboriginal community with alcohol on board their aircraft. There was outrage over it but eventually, with a bit of political spin, they managed to be exonerated of any misdemeanour. However, Aboriginal community people who have gone in with one empty can have been prosecuted and fined in their own communities. It has to raise the question of whether there is one law for one group and another law for the other.

I was recently in Mapoon talking to one of the community leaders up there, Ricky Guivarra. He said that in Mapoon they are looking at putting out signs in their community saying `Please don't feed the natives', because it is okay up there for non-Aboriginal people to have a drink but Aboriginal people are not allowed to. They have situations in Mapoon and other communities where they are trying to establish tourism operations to get away from the dependence on welfare, but they are having major problems now because they cannot even serve their guests a glass of wine with their meal at night. We have another situation up there where the canteens have been the primary source of income for many of these communities for many years. What has happened now? They have shut them down. The resources from those canteens were being used for a whole lot of community type projects. Now they are out of pocket. The state government has given no consideration to adjusting the losses from, in some cases, the only private enterprise income that came into those communities. Those incomes have gone. The councils have lost those, and now the people there are becoming more and more dependent on welfare.

It is a crazy situation that really needs to be addressed. The communities have to be compensated for those losses. Detoxification and alcohol treatment programs and medical treatment programs have to be brought into those communities today to deal with those people who already have those problems—and they have to engage the local communities. The Labor state government has to engage local community leaders with this. It has to offer them support and accept their advice on how to deal with this very serious problem, otherwise we are going to continue to see this farcical situation that we have up there at the moment where they are patting their backs in Brisbane and saying, `We've fixed the problem in Cape York,' and in Cape York the problem continues to grow. I am calling on Peter Beattie and his minister, Liddy Clark, who had a recent brush with the law herself in the `winegate' affair in Lockhart, to sit back and take note—and to take note of the recently elected state member for Cook, who was also caught up in that and, as a consequence, has come out himself and said that this system is not working. They should take advice from this newly elected state member, if not from me, and sit down and talk to local communities. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —In national politics it is sometimes easy to overlook the fact that we all come from local communities, that we all represent local communities and that our nation comprises a vast array of different local communities. So it was a great pleasure for me just a few minutes ago to meet with a very large number of children from the Belmont Primary School—from a local community in New South Wales in the electorate of the member for Shortland. It was especially pleasing to meet up with Mitchell Sanderson, who is the son of the people who run and own the Pelican Palms Motor Inn, which I happen to have had the pleasure of staying at when I visited the electorate a couple of months ago. Mitchell has a great interest in the parliament and the political system. It was tremendous to be able to foster and encourage that interest and also to talk to the kids from the school.

speech.para: I make this comment by way of introduction because I want to talk about the local community I came from, Orbost in East Gippsland, which I had the pleasure of visiting with the Leader of the Opposition very recently. A few weeks ago, the Today Tonight program featured two local communities as representative of the richest and poorest communities in our nation. They chose Mosman as representing the richest communities and, for reasons that I find hard to understand, they chose Orbost as representing the poorest parts of Australia. Some members of parliament may be pleased to say they come from the poorest part of Australia; I am not. I do not think the characterisation of the program was accurate. Indeed, I think it was an unfair representation of a town that has suffered significant economic change and some degree of economic decline but is nonetheless battling hard to grow and improve and is fighting back against the adverse economic pressures that have been affecting it over the last decade or two.

On 29 April, with the Leader of the Opposition, I had the pleasure of visiting a very important economic success story just outside Orbost, Snowy River Seeds, which grew from some predecessors that were cooperatives. I would like to express my very sincere thanks to the acting general manager, Leo Schoots, and his staff, who I met when the Leader of the Opposition and I visited there. Snowy River Seeds is involved mostly in processing sweet corn that is grown on the Snowy River flats, and it is exporting its product all around the world. It is engaging in significant R&D. It has a qualified genetics expert on staff, who is engaged in hybridisation design to get better quality seeds for export. It employs a dozen or so permanent full-time people and seasonally employs 20 or so casuals to process, sort and arrange the seeds. It is a real success story for the region. It processes the product that is grown in farms on the Snowy River flats, which have amongst the most fertile soil in Australia. It really does offer a beacon of hope for the East Gippsland economy, which has suffered significantly from economic change.

Until a couple of years ago, my father had a farm on the Snowy River flats. He grew beans until he ceased to be able to run the farm, which subsequently was share-farmed and involved sweet corn and various other things. Unfortunately, as a result of this trip, I have discovered that beans are no longer grown in the region because disease has affected the capacity to grow beans. It is great to see a beacon of economic recovery in East Gippsland. It was a tremendous experience for the Leader of the Opposition and me to visit Snowy River Seeds and see that a local, export oriented business that is adding value to the local economy and community is so successful in the region and is having such a marked positive impact on the economy of that local area.

I am proud of where I come from and I am proud of the effort, thought and commitment that is going into Snowy River Seeds. I am sure that it will play a major role in an economic resurgence for East Gippsland and help a struggling community gradually recover from the impact of economic change. As opportunities open up, as distance narrows, as broadband access eventually spreads throughout Australia, some of the barriers to economic success that currently afflict remote country towns like Orbost will start to melt away and we will see more and more economic resurgence from these communities. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —For some years now the Townsville community has been discussing what is called the Townsville port access road. After the Douglas arterial road, it is probably the most significant road project that our city should consider. It came out of the vision of David Carmichael, formerly chairman of the Townsville Port Authority, who saw that if you built a new road and a cross-river bridge and connected the port to the Stuart industrial area you would avoid the chicken and egg situation of no development occurring unless there is a road and no road occurring unless there is development. His view was simply that the community should get in and be visionary, build a new connection, and the development will follow.

speech.para: Unfortunately, the process through the Queensland government has seen this process stalled. I do not think there is any other word for it. It took four years to do the environmental impact assessments on the project when really you could have done them in six months. That has caused a problem for the federal government in relation to how we might assist by helping to fund that particular project. With the delay of so many years, the cost has blown out and there has probably been a $25 million increase in the cost, which is also unfortunate. Of course, the community has not had the benefit of being able to use that road because it is nowhere near in sight of being built.

We really need to assess where the project is at this time. The Queensland government wrote to the federal government on 22 December 2003 asking that the Commonwealth government consider the connection between the Flinders Highway and the Bruce Highway to be declared part of stage 1 of the new port access road, seeking Roads of National Importance funding. It further made a request in the same letter that an amount of $9.5 million was required, matching RONI funding, for planning corridor requisitions and detailed design. Unfortunately, based on the Queensland Department of Main Roads current timing for the proposals, development of stage 2 appears to be several years away, beyond the 2006-07 horizon. With design planning at an early stage, it may well yet cost significantly more than the current preliminary estimate of $75 million. It is a terrific shame for the community and for the development of our city that we are seeing these costs grow out of all proportion when we really could have had this whole thing built by now for about $50 million. I am hopeful that we might get higher priority on this and get the state government moving along. At this stage it certainly does not seem likely.

I turn quickly to the federal budget that was brought down on Tuesday night. I am pleased to see that this is a budget for families. Some will say it is a budget for everyone else as well—for older Australians, younger Australians, businesses and people who pay high marginal rates of tax—but primarily it has been a budget for families. I am really pleased to see that in my particular electorate defence has also been well and truly looked after by the federal government. We have almost $90 million going into looking after the men and women of the Australian Defence Force in Townsville alone. That is money that will be spent in the local community and will circulate in the local community. As well we have got $50 million of capital works going on in this next financial year. Again, that is money that will support the building and construction industry and keep jobs secure. It will also help to make sure that families can plan ahead with confidence.

It is particularly good to see Professor Ian Wronski from James Cook University with us this morning. JCU benefited by $128 million in the federal budget on Tuesday night, and I know that that money will be spent wisely and well. Thank you, Professor, for being with us today. We are about to go and do some more good work for James Cook University, and I hope we are successful in that.

talk.start.para: —I am privileged to be able to participate in this discussion this morning and inform you about a recent trip I had with NORFORCE. You will know, Madam Deputy Speaker Corcoran, that the Australian Defence Force Parliamentary Program provides members of parliament and senators with the opportunity to spend time with elements of the Australian Defence Force to gain a deeper understanding of the work being done by them in maintaining our security. I know you know this well, Madam Deputy Speaker, or Corky, as you are called—you will forgive me. As part of the program, I spent three days with NORFORCE, which operates across Northern Australia, principally in the Northern Territory and across the Kimberley.

speech.para: NORFORCE's role is to conduct surveillance and reconnaissance throughout Northern Australia, through the establishment of patrols in the particular squadron areas of responsibility, and grew out of the heroic deeds of the Nackeroos in the Second World War. NORFORCE makes sure it employs the special skills and knowledge of the local population, which is principally made up of Indigenous people in that part of Australia, and they form the majority of NORFORCE personnel. Indeed, between 60 and 65 per cent of NORFORCE comprises Indigenous personnel. I was heartened to see—as I am sure you were, Madam Deputy Speaker, when you undertook this brilliant experience last year—how hard NORFORCE has worked to provide real opportunities for these people and the positive effect it is having on local communities across the Top End and through the Centre.

There are four operational surveillance squadrons within NORFORCE: the Arnhem Squadron, headquartered at Nhulunbuy; the Centre Squadron, based in Alice Springs and responsible for the central and lower portion of the Northern Territory—its eastern border is shared with 51 Far North Queensland Regiment—the Kimberley Squadron, based in Broome in Western Australia; and the Darwin Squadron, based at Larrakeyah Barracks, which is the squadron I spent time with. The Darwin Squadron has a complement of 130 people, 60 per cent of whom are Indigenous. The squadron operates from the Tiwi Islands, where my time was spent—as was yours, Madam Deputy Speaker—and east to Manangrida and south to Wadeye. I was able to experience how NORFORCE patrols conduct their surveillance and how these exercises are planned, commanded, and conducted—as I know you were, Madam Deputy Speaker.

I want to mention the Commander of NORCOM, Air Commodore Steve Walker, who was kind enough to give me a briefing; and Lieutenant Colonel Clay Sutton, who is the commanding officer of NORFORCE. I also want to mention the members of the Darwin Squadron who participated in the exercise that I was involved in: Major Lloyd Scholes, Darwin, supervising officer; Captain Jacek Olchowik, Darwin, who is the officer in charge of all activities; Lieutenant James Morrison, Darwin, squadron headquarters liaison; Sergeant Chris Brannelly—a mate of mine for 20-odd years—Darwin, supervisor water operations; Corporal Cecil Black, Milikapiti, Melville Island, coxswain water operations 2IC; Corporal Phil Maker, Darwin, driver vehicle operations and tracker; Corporal Darren Rashleigh—who knows you fondly as Corky, Madam Deputy Speaker—Nauiyu-Daly River, vehicle operations 2IC; Lance Corporal Rob Korljan, Darwin, coxswain water operations; Private Clinton Barker, Darwin, advanced combat patrol first-aider, medic, and driver vehicle operations; Private Robbie Austral, Nauiyu-Daly River, scout vehicle operations; Private John Harris, Darwin, squadron headquarters signaller; Private Scott McKeon, Darwin, signaller water operations; Private Russell Yunupingu, Nguiu, Bathurst Island, signaller vehicle operations; Private Edward Tipungwuti, Nguiu, Bathurst Island, bowman water operations; and Private Andrew Portamini, Nguiu, Bathurst Island, coxswain water operations.

Madam Deputy Speaker Corcoran, I read those names into the Hansard because I know they were the same group of people who accompanied you. I was most impressed by their professionalism, energy, drive, knowledge and aptitude for the tasks they were given. I think they are a very good exemplar of how NORFORCE operates throughout its area of operations. NORFORCE plays a very important part in the defence of Northern Australia, particularly in terms of the surveillance of our coastline. It is a very integral part of our Defence Force and is an operational unit, unlike many other reservist units across Australia, and I thoroughly enjoyed the opportunity to spend time with them, as I know you did last year.

talk.start.para: —I thought it fitting today that in the middle of National Volunteer Week I take the time to thank and recognise the many volunteer workers in my electorate who do a marvellous job day in and day out. As someone who devoted a great deal of time to voluntary work before I entered this House, I know at first-hand how valuable, rewarding and important voluntary work is to our community and to our nation. It is definitely part of the Australian way of life—that is, giving a mate a hand, putting something back into our community and helping others. We are fortunate indeed that as a community we value and encourage voluntary work, and I firmly believe this work is what gives our local community its heart and soul.

speech.para: I have been delighted for the past seven years to host the annual Forde community contribution awards. I established these awards as a way of saying thank you to our local communities and to the many local residents who give their time so selflessly, never seeking recognition but always deserving it. Over the years we have had some remarkable recipients—many who have devoted 30, 40 and 50 years to voluntary work in a number of local charities and community organisations across Forde. I am also pleased to say that we have had a number of younger winners. It is great to see the next generation also contributing in this way and it certainly is a great sign of the future success of voluntary organisations in our community.

I am pleased to report to the House that we have again had some very outstanding recipients of the 2004 community awards. I will be formally presenting these awards next week, but I would like to take the time in this House today to inform members of the extraordinary people who have given a great deal of their time to our local communities: Mary Krueger of Fassifern Valley, Evan and Florence Roberts of Roadvale, Herbert Haupt of Cannon Creek, Elaine Gilmore of Boonah, Donald Lynch of Tamborine, Josephine Ferguson of Beaudesert, Lesley Rohan of Beaudesert, Karen Barney of Tamborine, Jane Bell of Coochin, Dawn Markwell of Beaudesert, Janet Dennis of Beaudesert, Murray Willmann of Beenleigh, Jacqueline McSwan of Beenleigh, Ian Bray of Eagleby, Kenneth Baker of North Tamborine, Frank Barnes of Mount Warren Park, and Marrianne Uhlmann of Cedar Grove. Our special community spirit award goes to Dean Sammut and Kathy Stone of Logan Village, and the group which has won the best contribution for 2004 is the Jimboomba Veteran Support and Advocacy Service. On behalf of our community and our nation, I thank these wonderful people for their hard work and dedication. All of our award recipients have been nominated by grateful local residents who have been touched by their kindness and generosity. I believe that one of the best aspects of my job is that I can recognise and thank our voluntary workers in this small way, and I look forward to continuing to host these awards well into the future.

I also want to take a little time to congratulate the 15 local community organisations which recently received funding from our Volunteer Small Equipment Grants. These grants were established by the government to help make the valuable work of our volunteers safer and more enjoyable. In the latest round, 15 community organisations in Forde got to share just over $32,700. This comes on top of several other previous rounds of funding. These grants will be of very real practical help to our local community organisations—for example, $4,108 will help Cedar Creek and Wolffdene Rural Fire Brigade to purchase CB radios, global positioning systems and weather meters. Some of the other community groups to benefit are the Beenleigh Soccer Club, Beaudesert Landcare, Community Care and Food Link, Tamborine Mountain Historical Society, Jimboomba Community Care and Boonah RSL. This is just a small example of the practical support these grants offer to our community organisations to help the volunteers and to support their work.

I am very pleased to be part of a government that recognises the value of our voluntary work and is offering real, practical assistance where it is most needed. In National Volunteer Week I want to thank most sincerely the recipients of the 2004 community contribution awards and all of the many residents in my electorate who do great voluntary work in schools, sporting clubs, charities, community groups, churches, hospitals, service clubs and other organisations. They do a marvellous job, and we are grateful as a community and as a nation for all their efforts.

debate.para: The following answers to questions were circulated:

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, upon notice, on 9 December 2002:

question.para: (1) On what date was the Dairy Exit Program (DEP) announced.
(2) On what date was the first DEP project approved.
(3) Who is eligible for DEP funding.
(4) How many applications for the DEP have there been to date.
(5) How many of these applications are from farmers who have also lodged a Claim After Sale form.
(6) How many of these applications are from farmers who have not yet lodged a Claim After Sale form.
(7) How many DEP grants have been approved to date.
(8) How many DEP grants have been paid to date.
(9) Of DEP grants approved, what is the average payment for each farmer.
(10) What is the total DEP expenditure to date.

talker.name: Truss, Warren, MP
Mr Truss
talker.role: Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The Dairy Exit Program(DEP) was announced as part of the Dairy Industry Adjustment Package on 28 September 1999.
(2) The first application approved under the DEP was in January 2001.
(3) To qualify for DEP funding, a person must:
have been be a farmer, and have been for a continuous period of at least two years immediately prior to applying for the DEP;
be over 18 years old;
be an Australian resident and living in Australia;
hold a Certificate of Inability to obtain finance from a financial institution;
be granted a payment right under the Dairy Structural Adjustment Program (DSAP) or the Supplementary Dairy Assistance (SDA) scheme; and
have applied by 30 June 2002.
(4) As of 29 February 2004, 171 initial applications for the DEP scheme had been lodged.

(5) As of 29 February 2004, of the 171 initial applications received there have been 107 `Claim After Sale' forms received. A further 60 `Claim After Sale' forms have been received from customers who were not required to lodge an initial application for the DEP Scheme.

(6) As of 29 February 2004, out of the 171 initial applications received there were 64 farmers who did not lodge a `Claim After Sale' form. While the deadline for DEP applications has passed, dairy farmers can now apply for exit assistance through the Farm Help Re-establishment Grant (Dairy Type Grant) scheme.
(7) As of 29 February 2004, 140 applications for the DEP payment had been approved.
(8) As of 29 February 2004, 140 claims for the DEP payment had been paid.
(9) The average payment under the DEP scheme is $42 658.
(10) As of 29 February 2004, $5 972 245 had been paid to farmers under the DEP.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 12 February 2004:

question.para: (1) Is he aware of the case of Bangladeshi journalist Salah Choudhury, Editor of the magazine Blitz.
(2) Is he aware that Mr Choudhury has been advocating, “dialogue and understanding between Jews and Muslims, formal and informal ties between his Islamic nation and Israel”.

(3) Is he aware that Mr Choudhury was arrested on 3 November 2003 as he was about to board a plane to address a writer's symposium in Israel sponsored by the apolitical organisation, the International Forum for the Literature and Culture of Peace (IFLAC).
(4) Is he aware that since then Mr Choudhury has been labelled a traitor and anti-Islamic as well as being threatened with charges of treason and anti-religious activities by police agents.
(5) Is he able to say whether Mr Choudhury is being held in compliance with his basic human rights.
(6) Is he aware that Mr Choudhury has been housed with the criminally insane, living in inhumane conditions and has been declined medical treatment.
(7) Is he able to say whether Mr Choudhury's court appearances were (a) fair and free, and (b) open to his family, advisers and international observers.
(8) Has Mr Choudhury been convicted of a crime; if so, what was his sentence.
(9) What is the Government's attitude towards Mr Choudhury's imprisonment.
(10) Has the Government made representations to the Bangladesh Government about his case; if so, (a) when, (b) to whom, (c) by whom, and (d) what was the response; if not, why not.
(11) What action does the Government propose to take in relation to Mr Choudhury's situation.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: I understand that Mr Choudhury was arrested on 29 November 2003. The specific circumstances of his arrest are unclear, but it appears that he is being held in Dhaka Central Jail. I understand that Mr Choudhury has not yet been convicted of any crime and that Police investigations are continuing. Since his arrest the Bangladesh press has reported allegations that he had been engaged in seditious activities. I am unable to comment on the substance of these allegations. The Australian High Commission in Dhaka has sought further information about the detention of Mr Choudhury from relevant authorities in Bangladesh, to which we do not have a response at this time.

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 1 March 2004:

question.para: (1) Is he aware of the campaign by the Police Federation of Australia to obtain an exemption for Australia's 50,000 police officers from the superannuation age preservation rules which prevent officers born after 1 July 1964 from accessing their entitlements before they reach 60 years of age?

(2) Is he aware that the principal reason for the Federation's campaign to ensure Australia's police are entitled to access superannuation from the age of 55 years is the concern that a police officer over the age of 55 years would be less effective and a risk to fellow colleagues when participating in duties which involve violent confrontation with offenders?
(3) Can he confirm that members of Australia's Defence Force can access superannuation benefits before the age of 55 years?

(4) Will he review the Government's superannuation policy so that Australia's police officers would be able to retire at the age of 55 years with access to superannuation entitlements; if not why not?

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes, I am aware of the campaign.
(2) Yes, I am aware that is the principal reason given.

(3) Yes, I am aware that members that joined the Defence Force prior to October 1991 can access their benefits prior to 55. New members after that date must wait until preservation age to access their benefits.
(4) Under the current law, superannuation benefits can be accessed at any age if the following conditions are met:
there has been termination of gainful employment; and
the benefits are taken in the form of a non-commutable life pension or annuity; and
the fund's governing rules cater for this type of payment.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Education, Science and Training, upon notice, on 2 March 2004:

question.para: (1) Is the Minister aware that when Workers Education Association Illawarra (WEA) was awarded the contract to provide English courses in January 2002 it was permitted to offer students 2 x 400 hours instruction over a two year period.

(2) Can the Minister confirm that WEA has been instructed to offer only 1 x 200 hours instruction to each student; if so, (a) why, (b) on what basis was the instruction to reduce student learning time made, and (c) is this consistent with the original contract; if not, why not.

(3) Is the Minister aware that as a result of this variation WEA anticipates that its enrolments will fall from 40 students per month to only 18 students between now and the end of the financial year.
(4) Will the Government now allocate further funding to English language programs in the 2004 Budget; if not, why not.
(5) Can the Minister give a commitment that more money will be allocated to English language programs when contracts are renewed following their expiry in December 2004; if not, why not.
(6) Will the Minister reinstate WEA's funding so that it can continue to improve the English language skills of constituents in the electoral division of Throsby; if not, why not.

talker.name: Nelson, Dr Brendan, MP
Dr Nelson
talker.role: Minister for Education, Science and Training

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes.
(2) WEA Illawarra has not been instructed to offer only 1 x 200 hours instruction to each student.

(a) The programme guidelines allow providers to offer clients between 120 and 400 hours of training in a placement depending on each individual clients training needs and a maximum of two rounds of training within a two year period from the date of the first training commencement.

(b) In 2003, in order to help providers manage within the budget allocated to the programme DEST introduced a new requirement that restricted the initial allocation of training hours to clients to 200 hours. This decision was taken following analysis of Language, Literacy and Numeracy Programme (LLNP) data which showed that more than 71% of job seekers were being allocated 400 hours of training. Given that over 69% of clients who withdraw from training did so before undertaking 100 hours of training, this was considered to be an inefficient use of resources which could be better directed to new clients.

(c) This arrangement is consistent with the original contract as it still allows providers to review client performance after delivery of between 190 and 200 hours (as a mid point review) and increase the number of hours to the maximum in the client's training plan and if the client is attending well, shows motivation and needs further training, then allocate increased hours to bring their total allocation up to a maximum of 400 hours.

DEST also negotiated with a number of providers to allocate additional funding to assist with the increased demand for the LLNP. However, the offer of this additional funding was contingent on providers implementing strategies to manage the increased demand within their budgets while still maximising the flow of new clients through the programme.

As part of this additional funding offer the Department offered WEA Illawarra an increase of $84,000 on their base funding allocation of $275,000 for English language training in 2003-04. On accepting this funding offer WEA Illawarra proposed, and the Department agreed to, the following strategies to be implemented for all new clients assisted with the additional funding:
Offering only 300 hours of training to those clients who are assessed as NRS level 1 or below;
Offering only 200 hours of training to those clients who are assessed as NRS level 2 or above; and
Offering second rounds of training to existing clients only in exceptional circumstances.

The implementation of these strategies for the new funding has been necessary to ensure that WEA Illawarra can maintain a flow of new clients and provide assistance to a greater number of jobseekers in the Illawarra region over the remaining LLNP contract period.

The Department continues to work with all providers facing high demand for programme places to ensure that these providers place client interests at the forefront of the strategies they implement to ration access to programme resources.

(3) According to DEST records WEA Illawarra had a client intake of 40 or more in the current financial year only once in July 2003. Over the period 1 July 2002 to 30 June 2003 WEA averaged an intake of just over 16 clients a month. Over the period 1 July 2003 to 30 December2003, WEA averaged a client intake of 14 per month and in the first three months of 2004 this has risen to an average intake of 18 per month. Over the period 1 January 2002 to 31 December 2003 around 43% of WEA clients achieved a successful outcome.

(4) The 2003-04 Portfolio Budget Statements forward estimates provide for an increase of funding to the LLNP of $3.671 million in 2004-05 (for a total of $44.373 million), of $4.751 million in 2005-06 (for a total of $45.453 million) and $5.751 million in 2006-07 (for a total of $46.453 million) compared to the programme's funding level in 2003-04 of $40.702 million.

(5) As noted above, the 2003-04 Portfolio Budget Statements forward estimates provide for additional funding of $14.173 million for the LLNP over the period 2004-5 to 2006-07 as compared the base funding level in 2003-04.
(6) In the 2002-03 financial year WEA Illawarra received $300,494 in funding for English Language Training. In the 2003-04 financial year WEA Illawarra has been allocated a budget of $359,000.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 2 March 2004:

question.para: (1) Is it correct, as stated by officers of the Minister's Department to the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee on 17 February 2004, that the Government has begun to trial the resettlement of unlinked offshore refugees in appropriate locations in regional Australia.
(2) In which particular locations are these trials (a) currently under way, and (b) proposed.
(3) How many refugees are proposed to be involved in the trials and what is the proposed timetable for their completion.
(4) As part of the trials, what funding will the Commonwealth provide for (a) on-arrival settlement services, and (b) other assistance to those participating in the trials.
(5) Are state and territory governments required to make a financial or other contribution to the trials: if so, what are the details.

talker.name: Hardgrave, Gary, MP
Mr Hardgrave
talker.role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs has been settling unlinked refugees in regional areas of Australia for some time. However, the Government is trialing a new approach to the selection of appropriate locations for future settlement in regional Australia with a view to more actively linking entrants to regional employment opportunities and necessary services.

(2) (a) In 2002-03, the Integrated Humanitarian Settlement Strategy (IHSS) assisted refugees to settle in Wagga Wagga and Wollongong in NSW, in Cairns, Townsville, Toowoomba, Gold Coast and the Logan/Beenleigh/ Woodridge region in Queensland, in Geelong and Shepparton in Victoria, in Launceston and the North West Coast region in Tasmania and in Alice Springs in the NT. In 2003-04 the IHSS also assisted refugees to settle in Coffs Harbour and Goulburn in NSW and in Mandurah in WA.
(b) In 2004-05, refugees will be settled in up to four new regional locations. These locations will be determined after consultation with State and Territory governments.

(3) The Government has set a notional target increase of 300-400 for 2004-05. Arrangements are intended to be ongoing, with the numbers settled in regional Australia being progressively increased taking into account the availability of employment opportunities and necessary settlement and other services.

(4) (a) On arrival settlement services will continue to be provided under the Integrated Humanitarian Settlement Strategy. The existing contractual framework already provides for service delivery in regional locations.

(b) Other Commonwealth funded assistance to new entrants settling in regional Australia will continue to be provided through the Adult Migrant English Program, the Community Settlement Services Scheme and mainstream service delivery programs.

(5) Initiatives to expand humanitarian settlement in regional areas will be implemented in close consultation with State, Territory and local governments. State, Territory and local governments would be expected to continue to meet their responsibilities for provision of health, education, housing and other mainstream services to new entrants settling in regional locations. States and Territories will be consulted in relation to other potential avenues for support for regional settlement.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 22 March 2004:

question.para: (1) In respect of the grant to the Tasmanian Environment Centre under the Grants to Voluntary Environment and Heritage Organisations (GVEHO) program, is he aware of the massive decrease in funding that the Tasmanian Environment Centre incurred in the 2003-2004 funding year.
(2) Is he aware that the Tasmanian Environment Centre provides assistance and support to other environmental organisations in Tasmania, such as Birds Tasmania.
(3) How does the Government justify cutting the organisation's funding so severely.

(4) What alternatives will the Government make available to organisations like the Tasmanian Environment Centre to ensure that they can continue to operate and provide the much needed resources and information that other environmental groups have come to depend upon them for.

talker.name: Kemp, Dr David, MP
Dr Kemp
talker.role: Minister for the Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes
(2) Yes

(3) I decided to offer grants to regional environmental organisations at three amounts depending on the size of the organisation and geographic area covered. The Tasmanian Environment Centre was offered the maximum grant.

(4) Since 1996, the Australian Government has dramatically increased the availability of funding to support environmental organisations like the Tasmanian Environment Centre through initiatives such as the Natural Heritage Trust and the Envirofund that annually provides $20 million for practical on-ground projects.

Indirectly, the Government subsidises environmental organisations through taxation concession schemes such as Income Tax Exempt Charities and Deductible Gift Recipients. Environmental Deductible Gifts Recipients received over $55 million in donations in the 2002-2003 financial year and these donations, in turn, resulted in payments to taxpayers of over $22 million.

Environmental organisations like the Tasmanian Environment Centre can take advantage of the very large amount of funding that the Government makes available to the environment sector through these funding programs and taxation concession schemes.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Employment Services, upon notice, on 23 March 2004:

question.para: What is the net impact on the budget of each placement under the Indigenous Employment Policy's Wage Assistance program (taking into account savings in unemployment benefits as well as the displacement and deadweight effects).

talker.name: Andrews, Kevin, MP

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 24 March 2004:

question.para: Has the Minister's department provided advice on whether the Migration Act 1958 remains consistent with international agreements; if so, has that advice indicated that the Act is consistent with international agreements and, if it is not, how is the Act inconsistent with international agreements.

talker.name: Hardgrave, Gary, MP
Mr Hardgrave
talker.role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: The Migration Act 1958 (Migration Act) is consistent with international agreements. Where consideration is being given to Australia becoming a party to an international agreement, consideration is given to whether any Act, including the Migration Act, will require amendment to ensure consistency with any obligations arising from that agreement.

When amendments to the Migration Act are proposed, international agreements are taken into account to ensure that the Migration Act will remain consistent with Australia's international obligations. This was the case, for example, when the Migration Act was amended in 1999 to allow interception and boarding of vessels suspected of carrying persons without visas to Australia.
