talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Health and Ageing, upon notice, on 24 March 2004:

question.para: (1) In respect of the announcement by the former Minister on 19 September 2003, what sum will be saved by the removal from the National Immunisation Program of the Diphtheria, Tetanus, Pertussis (whooping cough) vaccine given to children at 18 months of age.
(2) Have there been changes, or are changes contemplated, to the (a) Child Care Benefit, and (b) Maternity Immunisation Allowance payment.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The 18 month dose of diphtheria, tetanus and pertussis (DTPa) vaccine was removed from the National Immunisation Program on the recommendation of the Australian Technical Advisory Group on Immunisation (ATAGI). This dose was considered to be unnecessary as a result of the high level of immunity from the primary course at 2, 4, and 6 months of age. This dose also had an increased risk of local adverse events following immunisation.

Removing this unnecessary dose of DTPa, will result in a saving to the National Immunisation Program. As this was the only vaccine administered at 18 months, savings are also expected in relation to payments under the Medicare Benefits Scheme and notification payments to immunisation providers.

The ATAGI recommended the introduction of a dose of adult formulation diphtheria, tetanus and pertussis (dTpa) vaccine at 15-17 years, to replace the current dose of diphtheria and tetanus vaccine (ADT) vaccine provided at 15-19 years of age. The cost of replacing ADT with dTpa vaccine, taking into consideration the savings resulting from the removal of the 18 month dose of DTPa, is $5.36 million over four years.

(2) Effective from 19 September 2003, the 18 month dose of diphtheria, tetanus and pertussis (DTPa) vaccine was removed from the immunisation requirements for Child Care Benefit and Maternity Immunisation Allowance payments.

The legislation governing immunisation linkages to Child Care Benefit and Maternity Immunisation Allowance (A New Tax System (Family Assistance) Act 1999) is administered by the Department of Family and Community Services.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 25 March 2004:

question.para: (1) What progress has been made in implementing the Coastal Catchments Initiative for Port Phillip Bay?
(2) What is the total budget for the Coastal Catchments Initiative for the next two years?

talker.name: Kemp, Dr David, MP
Dr Kemp
talker.role: Minister for the Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) My Department is negotiating with Victorian authorities the development of Water Quality Improvement Plans for Port Phillip Bay and Western Port, as well as possible interim water quality projects.

(2) The total budget to date for the Coastal Catchments Initiative for the next two years is $1.82 million. This is comprised of $950,000 in 2004-05 and $870,000 in 2005-06. Additional funding will be subject to Natural Heritage Board decisions.

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 31 March 2004:

question.para: (1) What sum has the (a) Australian Taxation Office (ATO), and (b) Department of Treasury spent in the establishment of structures, services and resources to enable the collection of the excise on biodiesel.
(2) Have there been any projections of the ongoing costs to the Government for the collection of excise on biodiesel; if so, what are the ongoing costs likely to be.
(3) What sum does the Government anticipate will raise each year from biodiesel producers.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) (a) The ATO does not break-down its costs to the level of detail sought and is therefore unable to provide information on the establishment costs for the collection of excise on biodiesel.
(b) Not applicable. The ATO administers the collection of excise on biodiesel.
(2) There have been no formal projections of the ongoing costs of the collection of excise on biodiesel.
(3) See the revenue measure titled “Fuel tax reform” in the Treasury portfolio in Budget Paper No. 2, Budget Statement 2003-04.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 1 April 2004:

question.para: (1) In respect of the Sea Swap program announced by the Minister in the press release dated 24 October 2002, (a) which United States Navy vessels have participated in the Sea Swap program, (b) what was the type or class of each participating vessel, (c) at which Australian port did the transfer of each participating vessel's crew take place, and (d) what were the dates of arrival and departure for each participating vessel.
(2) Which agreement between the Australian and United States governments covers the operation of the Sea Swap program.
(3) What are the Australian government's obligations and what are the United States government's obligations under the Sea Swap agreement.
(4) Since October 2002, what costs have been incurred by the Australian Department of Defence as a consequence of the Sea Swap program.
(5) What is the planned duration of the Sea Swap program.

talker.name: Brough, Mal, MP
Mr Brough
talker.role: Minister for Employment Services and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) (a) The USS Fletcher on two occasions.
(b) The USS Fletcher is a Spruance Class Destroyer.
(c) Fremantle, Western Australia.
(d) USS FLETCHER arrived on 19 January 2003 and departed on 26 January 2003 and arrived again on 10 December 2003 and departed on 2 January 2004.

(2) There is no specific agreement that covers the operation of the Sea Swap program. The presence of the United States (US) personnel in Australia, participating in the Sea Swap program, has been conducted under the auspices of the Agreement between Australia and the United States of America concerning the Status of US Forces in Australia, and Protocol to that Agreement dated 9 May 1963.

(3) Australian Defence assistance, as requested by the US, is limited to the loading and unloading of military transport aircraft and accommodation of the crews. This assistance is provided under a `user pays basis' with cost recovery under existing agreements. In the absence of a specific agreement on the Sea Swap initiative, the only obligations placed on the Australian and US Governments are those legal and administrative obligations pursuant to the Status of Forces Agreement.

(4) The Sea Swap program is conducted under a fee-for-service arrangement. The US Navy has been charged for all costs associated with the two Sea Swap trials conducted to date. In addition, in order to meet ongoing Australian Defence Force needs, refurbishment work was conducted on accommodation blocks at Leeuwin Barracks at a cost of $250,825. As the US Navy has used these facilities during the two Sea Swap trials, they have contributed $25,000 towards the refurbishment costs.

(5) The Sea Swap program has been a trial conducted by the US Navy. The results of the program are yet to be evaluated for effectiveness by the Commander of Naval Surface Forces (US Pacific Fleet) and Commander-in-Chief (US Pacific Fleet). At this stage, there are no further US Navy ship visits planned to Australian ports as part of the Sea Swap initiative.
